Deutsche Bank has raised earnings per share estimates for cement companies under its coverage by 3-14% on assumption of better all-India pricing growth. 

The bank said Indian cement prices have been strong having gained 10% so far this year as industry cost leaders have lowered the competitive intensity and attempted to improve profitability after a weak calendar year 2018. Deutsche has raised its all-India pricing growth assumption by 6% year-on-year for the ongoing financial year from 4%, and has estimated that more upgrades are likely on the Street as improving realization trends are factored in.

Deutsche Bank has retained its buy call on ACC and raised target price to Rs 1,830 from Rs 1,790, and lifted target price to Rs 21,600 from Rs 19,330 on Shree Cement. 

The bank has raised target price on Ambuja Cement to Rs 235 from Rs 230 and increased UltraTech Cement target price to Rs 4,575 from Rs 4,240. 

Deutsche has raised target price on Ramco Cements to Rs 790 from Rs 785. 

Shares of these companies ended mixed in a subdued market on Tuesday. Shree Cement, UltraTech and Ramco ended down 0.2-0.6%, that of ACC and Ambuja ended up 0.3% and 0.1% respectively. 

While the bank has buy ratings on all these companies, ACC and Shree Cement are its top picks in the cement space. 
However, Deutsche sees demand growth moderating and believes monsoon will hold the key for recovery in demand. 
"Demand growth across most parts of the country has eased from the heightened double-digit levels seen in CY18, with channel members indicating demand has tapered to around 6-7% in recent months and is likely to be below 5% in April. 
They indicated a combination of election activity and low water tables have impacted volumes," said Deutsche. 

The India Meteorological Department has predicted a near normal monsoon this year at 96% of long period average while private forecaster has estimated that monsoon will be below normal at 93%.

Fear and greed tend to affect us and that is what we have to try to overcome in the market, said Kunj Bansal, Partner & CIO, 
Sarthi Group, in an interview with ETNOW. Edited excerpts:

At a time when we are seeing volatility spike, rising crude oil prices, how should one stay light and in position?
It has come after the market reached life high and barely corrected for a day or two from there -- 1% or 2%. When one is at a life high, the valuations tend to be expensive and it certainly becomes difficult to take a very short-term call on the market. 

If anyone wants to take a short-term call, one should be cautious and slightly worried about the sharp movement that the market has seen in the last one and a half to two months, close to 8%-9% of the indices. 

But one of the factors that in the recent past seems to be dominating the market movement is the oil price hike. The other factor is that the result season has started and that is something which is going to have an impact on individual stocks. General elections come every five years and the result will be out on 23rd May and that could have some shorter term impact on the market. 

If at all anyone wants to take a short term call, one should be cautious but those corrections also give an opportunity to buy on dips. If one is looking at around six months plus kind of view on the market, which is where we will again see the commercials, the economies, the numbers, the macro and micro dominating the stock performance and the market performance.


Will you buy on a 10% correction? I am not looking at Nifty individual stocks because some stocks have already corrected?
Yes, of course. Let us keep in mind that a 10% correction is a big correction. I am assuming that you are talking of largecap indices which will mean around 12%, 13%, 14% correction in the mid and smallcap indices and 15% to 20% correction in individual stocks. So, yes indeed! Let us also keep in mind that, fear and greed tend to affect us and that is what we have to try to overcome in the market. 

At a 10% correction, the market would have built in a lot of negatives including weak results. It would have possibly built in a further rise in oil prices which of course will have a negative impact on the macro economy. It also would have possibly built in some unexpected, unstable coalition kind of government which will have impact on the commercial and economic policies. It would have built in some of these factors and that is where the valuations would become attractive. Right now, we are close to life high and at life high you do not expect the valuations to be comfortable. In case of a 10% correction, the news flow would be far more negative than what it is today, but then good news and good prices do not come together. The bad news flow at that point of time will offer us good prices to invest and that is what we will do.


When it comes to earnings, bulk of the IT companies that have come out with their numbers. Infosys’ result is a bit mixed; TCS has come out with a very decent set. Wipro was a bit of a disappointment with the cut in margin guidance. How are you looking at prospects of the IT sector going forward?
From an investment point of view, we are at close to life high and valuations high. If at all one has to invest in this kind of a market, IT sector makes sense. Although historically IT’s valuations have not been anywhere comparable to consumer goods or consumer durables or the banking and financial services.

In terms of overall financials, the sector has been having a close to double digit growth. When we compare it to other sectors, their predictability is far lesser including for FMCG. Sometimes the rural growth or degrowth tends to affect them, sometimes the urban growth or degrowth tends to affect; weather patterns -- extended summer or extended winter and all those things -- have a bigger impact and as a result, the predictability of earnings for that sector is very low.

 Here you have a reasonably double digit growth with a very decent predictability with good margins, with cash flows, with regular dividends and now regular buybacks getting offered. In terms of risk adjusted investment, if one has to look, IT is a very good sector to invest in. So, my view there would be positive, One should be investing continuously although the share prices have moved in the recent past but given the way the companies have given highly differentiated results, it will have to be a very differentiated investment approach there. 

In terms of individual stocks, TCS despite having risen so much and reaching the upper end of its valuation, still remains a good investment. Infosys and Wipro are completely avoidable. It is difficult to understand what those companies are doing. Besides management issues, that Infosys continues to have, there is compression in the margins. But overall, as a sector, I am positive on IT.


What is your view on the cement pack? 
There are two-three things that one should look for in the cement sector. The top most factor is whether there is volume growth, with its ups and downs included, if we look at the last three-four years or so. We have had mixed views, mixed opinions, mixed numbers and mixed developments on the infrastructure sector, growth on investments, lack of private sector capex which has been compensated by government capex continuing. 

Volume growth has continued to be in the range of 5%-6% on the lower side to 7%-8% volume growth on the upper side. Despite having mixed observations on our economy, in last three-four years, this has been one sector which has been continuing to report growth. Taking that factor further, obviously the next thing is the margins. 

Leaving aside, last one and a half quarter, there were pressures on the margins because increased raw material costs have settled in and we saw some uptick in the margins of cement companies selectively in the December quarter. We should see that trend continuing in the March quarter.

In March, we have seen sharp movement, sharp upward movement in some of the cement stocks. Shree Cement is one. If I saw correctly, it is probably trading at a 52-week high and as a result, obviously at a reasonably high valuation. I see the growth continuing there even if I take the next one year view. 

Margins which were under pressure are improving and despite being commodity-oriented companies, there is a reasonably decent control on the leverage broad as a sector overall. There are some companies which are of course quite net cash positive. Some are borrowing but a very limited borrowing with well controlled leverage.


What is your reaction going to be if SoftBank indeed decides to invest in Jio? 
It is positive from two-three angles. They are getting the backing of a strong financial investor. There may not be a technological input from them. Two, this will result in cash flows. It has to be seen what is the structuring that they do. If the money that will be flowing in is not through the sale of shares from the holding company, then the money would not come into the holding company and cannot be used to retire debt. But if it comes that way, then that will be helpful to reduce debt. 

If it comes as a subsidisation of Jio business, then it will be used for further expansion, which is where, given the way the industry is currently shaped up and the way the aggressiveness is likely to continue, they will continue to need money.

Overall, it is positive. The details can only be worked out when one has finer granular details on valuations, stake sale, actual amount of money flowing in etc. 

Also, nobody knows what will happen to the market in the shorter term but I am looking at it from the point of view of six months from now. So, by October-November, assuming that all the political related volatility has set in, the market would continue to attract FII interest. I think a large part of FII money will keep looking for largecap liquid names and which is where we know Reliance with the largest market cap almost Rs 8.5 lakh crore, will keep attracting buying interest from FIIs, besides the domestic interest that has also continued. This stock will continue to be in demand. Keeping the shorter term volatility aside, it is a positive development and from investment recommendation also, it is a positive in the medium term.

NEW DELHI: Around 19 stocks rose to touch their 52-week highs on NSE in Thursday's session.

Among the stocks that touched their 52-week highs were Bajaj Finserv, Balaxi Ventures, Balrampur Chini Mills, Brightcom Group, DCB Bank and Dr. Reddy's Lab.

Dhunseri Ventures, HCL Technologies, KPIT Technologies, Bank of Maharashtra, Reliance Industries, SHREE CEMENT, SRF, Titan Company,UltraTech Cement and Wipro also featured among the stocks that touched their 52-week highs on NSE.

Benchmark NSE Nifty index was trading 46.10 points up at 11,772.25 while the BSE Sensex was trading 123.56 points up at 39,178.24. 

Overall, 31 shares were trading in the green in the Nifty50 index, while 19 were trading in the red. 

In the Nifty 50 index, UltraTech Cement, Grasim Inds., YES Bank, BPCL and UPL were among the top gainers. 

While Bharti Infratel, Vedanta, Infosys and ONGC were trading in the red.

From a long-term perspective, it does not look like a structurally very big change is happening for Idea or Airtel, said Siddhartha Khemka, Head of Retail Research, 
  
  
  , in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts:

What is your assessment of the kind of earnings that we have seen so far? Will there be a recovery or an improvement in headline numbers?
Yes, generally we see that the initial round of results that come in are in line or better than expectations. The back-benchers who are the culprits in pulling down the overall results come in later. So far, we have seen good numbers from banks like HDFC Bank; on the corporate banking side, we have seen good numbers from Axis. 

The auto sector has given weaker numbers but that was on expected lines. The volume details were already out. The negative surprise from Maruti in terms of the margins was something which will impact the segment for some more time but so far, the overall results have been broadly in line with expectations so far. 


Within pharma, are you looking at any specific names as good buys?
Pharma has so far been a mixed bag, a difficult sector to track because a lot of things are happening apart from the regulatory actions. A lot of these companies -- some of which are able to crossover to get a clearance - -are seeing some positive reaction. A lot of these companies are unable to do that and are consistently getting observations one after the other and are getting impacted. 

Apart from that, the pricing pressure continues to impact the pharma space. Volume growth is another factor, wherein the US and Europe is yet to pick up. Overall, only a handful of them have been able to do well. One of them is Divi’s Lab, which has consistently done well. It has cleared all the regulatory challenges and has been reporting good numbers. 

Apart from that, companies like Dr Reddy’s and Lupin on the larger front and Auro Pharma are starting to report good numbers and expectation of good delivery apart from the comfortable valuations are something are aiding some of these names in pharma space. 


Is there anything that appeals to you in the cement space? Do you believe that the overall cycle is turning fairly positive and that the demand supply mismatch now seems to be narrowing? Are fundamentals in favour of the space?
Cement is a very interesting space currently because of the subdued numbers that they have been reporting for quite some time. However, the capacity utilisations have now picked up. A lot of consolidation has happened, no new capacities are now being added and finally we should see going into FY20 some of the improvement in realisation and some raw material pressures easing off leading to healthy margins. 

Volumes for the space have been pretty strong. In the last couple of quarters we have seen the heavyweights reporting high single digit to some of the smaller names reporting double digit volume growth as well. It was the main concern was on the realisation front as well as on the cost front. 

In the last couple of months, the south-based companies have been increasing the prices which led to some volume not picking up in that space. However, in north- based companies, consolidation has happened and these should do consistently well. So, it is a structural change.We saw that in the very strong numbers for UltraTech Cement. It is much better than expectation and the street is becoming incrementally positive towards the stock. 

We are preferring some of the pockets in the cement space right from UltraTech, Shree Cement and JK Cement which is again a north-based player and Ramco Cement which in the southern market looks attractive in the overall cement space. 


What is your sense on the earnings of Piramal Enterprises?
I briefly had a look at the headline numbers. On its own it is a good set of numbers but compared to street expectations, there has been a miss and there was an one-time expense that the company has taken which is negatively impacting the sentiments as of now. 

Otherwise, the other broad operating parameters look pretty steady. Once we have a con-call with the management, things would get clarified. The street would take in things as it would get more details about the numbers and that should allay the negative sentiments. 


What is the expectation from Yes Bank? I guess one would be looking out for what strategy Ravneet Gill has in mind for next one to two years?
We are expecting a 24% year-on-year on loan book growth, mainly driven by the retail banking business. The NIMs are expected to remain stable at 3.4%; we expect PAT of about Rs 970 crores for Q4. 

The key things to watch out for is the fund-raising plans that the bank would have. That is a major block in terms of how the bank is able to grow in future. Due to management issues, they have not been able to come down and raise equities because at the pace they are growing, they would need fresh equity to charter their new growth plans. 

We have been hearing the news of a change in the entire top management. How the new CEO takes that forward, who are the new people who would join would definitely be something that the street would watch out for.


What is your take on the telecom space as a whole? The two incumbents are readying their war chest to take on rival Jio. Is there some potential for upside? 
Telecom has been another interesting sector at least in the current juncture where we are seeing two of the three larger players are coming out with rights issues, raising a war chest as you rightly said. The only issue is one needs to be cognisant of the fact that how long will this war chest last, given that the new player Jio is consistently on the prowl for market share.

They would need to continuously do a higher capex to move to the newer technologies, upgrade the service networks and the likes. So yes, at the current valuation, it does look like that on the back of the current fundraising, both Airtel as well as Idea could see some decent upside. We have also heard the Reliance management is still looking at increasing market share and not much of ARPU gains.

So for some more time, this fight would continue but eventually there would be some improvement in ARPUs which would help the entire sector. However, from a long term perspective, this does not look like a structurally very big change happening especially for the Idea as well as Airtel because of the capex-heavy nature. The debt would not go off. They would need to pay for the existing spectrum that they have bought and the incremental capex required for moving up the technology ladder would continue to keep up pressure on the balance sheet. 

So it is a tactical opportunity right now and may not be a long-term opportunity for retail investors.

NEW DELHI: The domestic equity market trod water on Tuesday, as investors resorted to profit booking on disappointment over March quarter earnings of select bank and auto heavyweights, including YES Bank and Hero MotoCorp. 

Weak global sentiment, a 1 per cent rise in crude oil prices, caution ahead of US Fed policy review and speculation over key macroeconomic data such as March fiscal deficit and infrastructure output data were the other key factors that hit investors’ risk appetite. 

Gains in IT shares, including those of Infosys, HCl Technologies and TCS, despite a stronger rupee, helped the market pare much of the losses. 

"Investors resorted to profit booking as weak results from banks and auto hit investor sentiment. However, a late recovery in IT and metal stocks helped minimise losses,” said Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services.

Sensex closed 36 points lower at 39,031 while Nifty settled 7 points down at 11,748.


We walk you through the highlights of Tuesday's session:

YES Bank suffers biggest-ever fall Shares of the private lender closed 29.23 per cent down at Rs 168, logging its biggest-ever percentage fall in a day. The lender disappointed the Street with its March quarter numbers on Friday. Several analysts have downgraded YES Bank and cut price targets after the lender reported its first-ever quarterly loss.


Jet shares extend lossesShares of Jet Airways declined 8.37 per cent to close at Rs 153.30, extending the losing streak into a third consecutive session. The scrip has come off 10.48 per cent in last three sessions. ET reported this morning that a section of its employees has evinced interest in bidding for the airline and is scouting for investors to get the airline flying again. 


TVS Motor falls ahead of Q4 nosShares of TVS Motor Company closed 4.03 per cent down at Rs 486 ahead of its fourth quarter numbers. Post-market hours, the company said its March quarter profit fell 19 per cent to Rs 134 crore from Rs 166 crore in the corresponding quarter a year ago. 


Godrej Prop tanks despite strong Q4 nosGodrej Properties reported a 270.53 per cent year-on-year rise in consolidated net profit at Rs 156.66 crore for the quarter ended March 31, 2019. It had posted a net profit of Rs 42.28 crore in the corresponding quarter last year. However, the numbers failed to cheer the market and the stock shed 3.20 per cent to settle at Rs 829.70. 


Hero MotoCorp shares fall 4% Shares of Hero MotoCorp closed 3.51 per cent lower at Rs 2,512.65 after it reported a 24.51 per cent year-on-year fall in profit at Rs 730 crore for March quarter. Brokerages have trimmed price targets on the stock by as much as 8 per cent. 


RCap shares plunge 8%Falling for the third day in a row, shares of Reliance Capital closed with a loss of 8.47 per cent at Rs 132.85. In the last three sessions of losses, shares of the company have come off 14.48 per cent. As per an ET report, Reliance Home Finance (RHFL) and Reliance Commercial Finance (RCFL) will seek to raise funds through the sale of fresh equity as holding company Reliance Capital is willing to cede ownership to new investors at the right price. 


Kotak Bank flat after Q4 nosPrivate lender Kotak Mahindra Bank reported a 25.24 per cent year-on-year rise in standalone profit at Rs 1,407.80 crore for the March quarter as provisions fell sharply. Shares of the company closed 0.65 per cent higher at Rs 1,387.


156 stocks hit 52-week lowsAs many as 156 stocks, including Hero MotoCorp, MRF, Cox & Kings, HEG, Rallis India and Reliance Power, hit their 52-week lows on BSE. On the other hand, Aurobindo Pharma, UPL, Wipro, Bajaj Finserv, HCL Technologies, PVR, Shree Cement and SRF were among the 40 stocks that hit their 52-week highs.


Over 200 stocks hit lower circuitsAs many as 201 stocks, including Indiabulls Integrated Services, Lakshmi Vilas Bank, Eveready Industries, Mahamaya Steel Industries, 8K Miles Software Services and Prabhat Dairy hit their lower circuits. On the other hand, Signet Industries, 63 Moons Technologies, Prakash Steelage and Darshan Orna were among 102 stocks that hit their upper circuits. 


122 stocks signal potential fallMomentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bearish crossovers on 122 counters on BSE. Among them were Mindtree, Jaiprakash Associates, ITC, Rain Industries, Biocon, Hero MotoCorp and Fortis Healthcare and Jubilant Life Sciences. Meanwhile, 54 counters, including JSW Steel, ICICI Bank, BPCL, Hathway Cable, PVR, Hexaware Technologies and Oil India, showed bullish crossovers.

ITC, Nestle, Marico and United Spirits are the four consumer stocks that can emerge as value creators, said Sanjiv Bhasin, Executive Vice President, IIFL Securities, in an interview with ETNOW. Edited excerpts:

Which two-wheeler or four-wheeler stock would you buy in this decline? 
We are very optimistic on three names: a) Ashok Leyland. Given that they are enlarging their market share in both LCV and MHV segments; their new intermediate commercial vehicle (ICV) launch has taken off brilliantly and that they would be manufacturing 50% of the buses and out of that, a large share would be in Gujarat on the EV side. They are now looking at CIS countries to improve their content on the export side. So Ashok Leyland is no brainer at these prices. 

b) Eicher, given that we know there were ten days of manpower hours lost because of the strike in the Enfield factory but now it is up and running. Their franchise is growing strongly and at 20,000, there is an extremely good risk reward for a 20% upside. 

c) Bajaj Auto. Again their pan sub-continent sales and margins which they sacrificed for gaining market share has played out well and Bajaj Auto is now going to take on Enfield head on. 

These three stocks would stand out. But as a whole, if you are looking for the best wealth creator in the last seven-eight years and you are getting a price opportunity, then you should be buying some mutual funds or a SIP in some of the largecaps which could stand to gain out. Tata Motor would be a dark horse but the price performance has played out well. We still think if it comes closer to Rs 180-190, it will again become a very good value play.


The larger picture continues to be that while numbers in itself were fine, but even with Britannia, we are seeing the management talking about weak macros going ahead as well. Would you look at value when it comes to this segment of the market?
Britannia numbers are slightly disappointing but otherwise this stock has been on a tear and it has been gaining market share. The time margins have been slightly skewed.

But if you want to play that segment, there is ITC. A disclosure -- ITC has been one of our top picks and relatively has done nothing -- but on the downside it does not break Rs 265 and now it is finding strength close to Rs 305-310. 

ITC has gained a huge market share in the biscuit market and they have sacrificed margins to gain market share. Now those businesses are stabilising. I would expect ITC to be a dark horse to give you at least a 50% upside in the next two years. So ITC, Nestle, Marico would be standouts. Britannia on corrections I would avoid at this price. The other three are going to be outperformers. You can add United Spirits given the ascent and the numbers which their franchise model has turned out. A large part of the consumption market is now raring to go with the hot summer. These could be relative value creators in the next six to nine months. 


Two years ago, nobody thought there could be such a pronounced slowdown in the entire HFC space. If HFC disbursements are slowing down, what does that mean for consumer durables, for discretionary and other allied sectors?
Look at the performance of cement majors. UltraTech numbers were the best ever you heard. 104 million tonnes of capacity and utilisation playing out. Margins are much better than expected in a lean season, which tell you a) cement and steel demand is up and running. b) A large number of men from the boys have been sifted out in the NBFC/IL&FS fiasco; and c) Low-cost housing as a theme continues to remain robust given the numbers, if you compare it with an HDFC. Gruh Finance has been in the eye of the storm after that merger and in the small ticket Rs 10 to 15 lakh, it has been an outperformer as far as numbers and earnings go. At 15% growth rate for quarter on quarter, I do not know how many 10-12 quarters I have seen but yes there is evidence of that. 

The three catalysts – one, low interest rates globally; two, bond yields touching new lows and three, the transmission effect -- a large part of PSU and other retail banks are now taking the market share away from NBFCs. The second half could be fairly robust and the numbers from quality names like Godrej and Oberoi, both are showing a lot of traction on the upside. 

You will have to take it with a pinch of salt, if you want to be , in the names which have shown a pedigree management and outperformance in this fiasco. I could name UltraTech, Shree Cement, ACC on the cement side, HDFC, LIC Housing and maybe a dark horse in L&T Finance on the second side and thirdly it would be some of the building companies – NBCC and dark horse called Shankara Building Products which has weathered a lot of storm and could outperform in the next one year.


There is no linearity in Federal Bank’s numbers; Q2 was good, Q3 was not that interesting. The management believes the worst of the NPA cycle is behind them but I do not see any evidence of growth. Why should one buy an old private bank , when growth is slowing down? 
The simple answer is that if Kotak is seeing a gain in market share on the largecaps, then surely Federal Bank, DCB are going to take a prime part of the problem which have been plaguing the NBFCs and we see more of plateauing over there. Stick with pedigree names. The worst of the eye of the storm was during the Kerala floods. You had mouthwatering valuations at that time. There is a lot of froth now. But on a valuation basis and given that a lot of money comes in through the NRI route in Kerala and their franchise, all the three banks would stand out in that order. We want to be here growth is going to be an outperformer because of the NBFCs and credible management, which all three have displayed over the last one year.

The domestic equity market showed extremely divergent behaviour during the week gone by. While the smallcap index Nifty100 was down 1.5 per cent, Nifty50 was almost flat with a downward bias. Even Nifty500 index, which covers 75 per cent of the market cap, traded sideways. Sectorally, weakness was visible in the auto sector, which is the biggest barometer to measure the mood of the masses.

Given the precipitous fall in April numbers for passenger vehicles, two-wheelers and tractors, prices of auto players should have tanked. However, despite the headwinds, these companies have stood their ground and haven’t fallen drastically. This is solely because of the impact of ‘Global Liquidity’.

Given the US Fed’s status quo on interest rates at least for this year, global liquidity will flow into emerging countries like India where they can capture 7.5 per cent kind of growth, whereas the US economy is expected to grow at 2.5 per cent. This will also lead to massive dollar inflows which can take the rupee to Rs 65 66 level by the year end.


Event of the Week
Just when we thought the NBFC crises is taking a breather, the condition has resurfaced. With rating agencies downgrading Reliance Home Finance and Reliance Capital’s long-term debt, the market has turned wide eyed in fear. This debt implosion could have further cascading effects if RBI and the government do not act quickly. Hopefully post elections, things should be under control. Nonetheless, such turbulence is not reflected in the stock market yet.


Technical Outlook
Nifty50 is hovering near its all-time high level, neither breaking highs nor breaking lows. Though smallcap indices have cracked, Nifty50 is still resilient, indicating that eventually the highs will be breached and Nifty will move into a new territory. However, in the intermediate period, till such time the breakout does not occur, it is better to avoid trading. A decisive break above 11,900 should be used as an opportunity to go long or a break below 11,550 should be taken as an opportunity to go short.

Agencies

Expectations for the Week
The domestic market is expected to remain choppy over the next few weeks due to the quarterly earning numbers and the overhang of the election outcome ahead. Among various sectors, IT is expected to witness some cooling off as it has run up a lot. Private sector banks and cement companies, especially Ultratech and Shree Cement, can also experience some profit booking while PSU banks led by SBI can bounce back.

The smallcap and midcap space is more likely to experience an uptick as sentiment towards the likelihood of yet another term for the ruling party grows. On the commodity front, avoid metals as commodity prices are correcting internationally. Investors should start looking for stocks in the smallcap space and keep them on their watchlist till the election outcome on May 23.

Nifty50 closed the week 0.35 per cent down at 11,712

By Ashish Chaturmohta Head – Technical & Derivatives, Sanctum Wealth Management

Current chart structure, according to technical analysts, looks sluggish and investors are advised to remain light on positions. Some of the technical picks where investors can catch dips for 10-15 per cent return in short term are DMart, NHPC, Bharat Forge, Hero MotoCorp and Tata Motors, they said.


Where we are: Month of April was a range bound for the market and May has got off on the same note. Though Nifty witnessed breakout above previous high of 11,760 and touched new all-time high of 11,856 last month; market is largely sideways in the range of 250 points since last five weeks.


What is in store: Index hasn’t broken its previous swing low of 11,550 thus, maintaining sequence of higher highs and high lows. Hence 11,550 becomes pivotal support level for the market. However, breaking below 11,550, market will see break in current uptrend and profit booking will emerge in the market initially towards 11,350-11,310 levels. On the upside 11,800-11,860 will act as resistance zone for the market. Crossing above 11,860 on sustainable basis, Nifty will see fresh breakout. Then Index can rally initially towards 12,000 and 12,300.


What could the investor do: In Nifty weekly options, maximum open interest for Puts is seen at strike price 11,700 followed by 11,600; while for Calls it is seen at strike price 11,800 followed by 12,000. Good amount of Call writing was seen in 11,800 and 11,850 indicating as immediate resistance zone for the market. India VIX closed at 24.03 up by 10.7 per cent for the week. After some relief in volatility the previous week, it has picked up again. Expect VIX to remain at elevated levels and rise further as markets heads towards election results later in the month. On stock specific front UPL, DCB Bank, Reliance Industries, Shree Cements and ICICI Prudential Insurance are showing strength.

Reliance Securities has given a hold recommendation on Shree Cements with a target price of Rs 21,000.

Shares of Shree Cements traded at Rs 20,613.95 around 1:30 pm on 21 May, 2019. The brokerage has set a one-year horizon for the stock to hit the target price.


March quarter highlights:



"Shree Cement (SRCM) reported a strong operating performance in 4QFY19 aided by healthy cement sales volume and improved cost efficiency. Ebitda grew by a strong 35 per cent YoY and 19 per cent QoQ to Rs 850 crore in-line with our estimate," the brokerage said.
EBITDA per tonne stood at healthy Rs 1,103 against Rs 958 in Q4FY18 and Rs 1,067 in Q3FY19.
Sales volume, including clinker, grew by strong 13.3 per cent YoY and 23 per cent QoQ to 7.3mnT, while power volume stood at 382 million units (up 11 per cent YoY and down 15 per cent QoQ).
Cement operating cost per tonne stood at Rs 3,122 (down 2.4 per cent YoY and down 3.8 per cent QoQ) mainly due to reduction in freight cost per tonne (down 11 per cent YoY and down 3 per cent QoQ) and other expenditures per tonne (down 2 per cent YoY and down 4.8 per cent QoQ).
A higher-than-expected depreciation dragged its net profit by 20 per cent YoY (up 11 per cent QoQ) to Rs 320 crore. 


Outlook and valuation:

"We believe SRCM has been moving in the right direction in its pursuit to dominate the markets by adding capacity at regular intervals," the brokerage said.

The brokerage expects the company to grow market share with strong profitability without much stress on balance sheet. 

"Its premium multiple is expected to sustain, which can be supported by thin liquidity and meagre non-institutional holdings. However, as current valuations look to be stretched despite upgrading our estimates, we downgrade our recommendation on the stock to hold from buy with a revised SOTP-based target price of Rs 21,000," the brokerage added.

Phillip Capital (India) has given a buy recommendation on Shree Cements with a target price of Rs 22,500.

Shares of Shree Cements traded at Rs 20,578.10 around 2:45 pm on 21 May, 2019. The brokerage has set a one-year horizon for the stock to hit the target price.

As per the brokerage, Shree has proven its ability to remain sustainable on operating numbers despite strategic shift. 

The brokerage thinks the company's better adaptability and flexibility against peers to changing business environment will be the next driver for its earnings and valuation multiples.

In the conference call post March quarter earnings, the management commentary showed the intent of improving price realisations with conscious efforts to align volume growth in order to achieve this, the brokerage said, adding, that the outlook on demand remains and cement prices remains positive.

"Focussing in a big way on supply-chain efficiencies which will be an added advantage for Shree in our view in the longer term. From our on the ground checks, we continue to see structural initiatives by Shree to improve efficiencies on this front," the brokerage said.

"We retain buy and revise our price target to Rs 22,500 against Rs 18,500 earlier. We value Shree at 18 times FY21 EV/Ebitda. At Rs 22,500, the stock will trade at nearly $250 per tonne. It presently trades at $210 per tonne," said the brokerage.

By Chandan Taparia
Nifty opened positive on Thursday and made a new lifetime high of 12,041 in morning session after leads and trends showed a clear majority verdict for the incumbent BJP in the general election 2019. But the market failed to hold on to the gains and drifted sharply by around 400 points from the higher level.

It formed a Bearish Candle on the daily scale and closed negative by breaking below the previous two-days’ low of 11,680. It wiped out all the gains of the session and hovered near its weekly opening level. Nifty has to respect to its multiple support at 11,550 to regain strength and move towards 11,761 and then 11,888 levels, while below 11,550, weakness could be seen with every change in price setup.

On the options front, maximum Put open interest was at 11,000 followed by 10,500 levels, while maximum Call OI was at 12,000 followed by 12,500. There was marginal Call and Put writing in the market.

India VIX fell sharply by 29.77 per cent to 19.04 level. India VIX made a new record high of 30.18 on Wednesday and fell drastically after election results. Now, it has to cool down below 16 to get short-term stability in the market.

Bank Nifty opened positive and made a new lifetime high of 31,705 but failed to hold the gains and corrected by around 1,400 points from the day’s high. It closed negative and formed a Bearish Candle, but managed to continue the formation of higher lows for the fifth consecutive session. Now it has to hold its immediate support at 30,250 to regain strength towards 31,000 level while major support exists at 30,000 and then the gap area near 29,500.

Nifty futures closed negative at 11,713 with a loss of 0.58 per cent. Long buildup was seen in Ujjivan Finance, Bank of Baroda, Shree Cement and IndusInd Bank while shorts were seen in ITC, HDFC Bank, Apollo Hospital and Allahabad Bank.


(Chandan Taparia is Technical & Derivative Analyst at MOFSL. Investors are advised to consult financial advisers before taking an investment calls based on these observations)

NEW DELHI: Technical analysts are optimistic on Dalal Street. They expect Nifty50 to touch the 12,000 mark on a closing basis sooner than later, with the positive momentum broadening to second-rung stocks.

Technical charts are signalling broader participation, and nearly 120 stocks on NSE now look set for a strong rally, as suggested by moving average convergence divergence, or MACD.

The momentum indicator signalled an bullish crossover – a sign of bullish undertone – on these counters, hinting at possible upsides.

These stocks have been witnessing strong trading volumes of late, lending credence to the emerging trend.

The list included shares of steelmakers like SAIL, Tata Steel, JSW Steel and JSPL and banks such as South Indian Bank, Union Bank, IDFC First Bank, Karnataka Bank and Bank of Maharashtra.

Among others, Coal India, HDFC Life, InterGlobe Aviation, Future Enterprises and Torrent Power are a few other names on the list.









The MACD is known for signalling trend reversals in traded securities or indices. It is the difference between the 26-day and 12-day exponential moving averages. A nine-day exponential moving average, called the signal line, is plotted on top of the MACD to reflect 'buy' or 'sell' opportunities. 

When the MACD crosses above the signal line, it gives a bullish signal, indicating that the price of the security may see an upward movement and vice versa.

Data showed seven stocks are showing bearish trends. They included Manpasand Beverages, Page Industries, L&T Infotech, Blis GVS Pharma and Bajaj Consumer Care. 



The MACD indicator should not be seen in isolation, as it may not be sufficient to take a trading call, just the way a fundamental analyst cannot give a 'buy' or 'sell' recommendation using a single valuation ratio.

Traders should make use of other indicators such as Relative Strength Index (RSI), Bollinger Bands, Fibonacci Series, candlestick patterns and Stochastic to confirm an emerging trend.

As far as Nifty50 is concerned, daily strength indicator RSI is moving upward and above its reference line, signalling a positive bias. Besides, the formation of higher top and bottom on the daily charts indicate that Nifty supports are shifting higher.

“If the 50-pack crosses and sustains above 11,970 level, it would witness buying, which can lift the index towards the 12,000-12,050 range. However, if the index breaks below 11,900, it would head towards the 11,850-11,820 range.


Understanding MACD


A close look at the stock chart of SAIL shows whenever the MACD line has breached above the signal line, the stock has shown an upward momentum and vice versa. On Tuesday, the stock traded 0.4 per cent down at Rs 53.40 on BSE.

The revival in the earnings is not visible on a broad-based basis for the next couple of quarters. I definitely think that one should avoid the stocks which have been beaten down and where you are not seeing much growth visibility, said Hemang Jani, Senior VP, Sharekhan, in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts:


The Indigo numbers are nothing short of a blow out. How much more headroom is left for Indigo? It has almost become a duopoly kind of a space now?See the market at this point of time is so polarised that wherever you see a good growth visibility and some stable margins, the money is only chasing those sort of stocks. And that is what we have seen in the last whole year, last six months or so. So we have very few stocks where one can really have a growth visibility. The Indigo management is telling us that in terms of international and domestic operations, they are extremely well placed. They are also going to get delivery of almost about 20-25 aircraft. 

The passenger growth has not been that great but even if it remains about 12-15% with only two major players. The overall environment is extremely favourable and so though the stock has run up, given the state of the market, we might see some more upside for a player like Indigo. 


I always thought that Divi's had this API model which was almost like an annuity business. Irrespective of what is happening to the pharma world, Divi's had a strong disruptive model.Yes, particularly after this US FDA related issue got resolved, the company started delivering good set of numbers and the good thing about Divi's is that unlike most of the other pharma companies which have a lot of dependence on the generic opportunity and the deal with pricing related issues, Divi's had a very different business model. 

But given the fact that the entire sector in the US and in many parts of the world is going through challenges in terms of litigation, etc, and when you are supplying to some of those pharma majors, somewhere you will also have to take a hit in terms of the slowdown whenever it happens. In case of Divi's, we have seen that but overall the business model and the margins part is playing out extremely well. So we are not too negative on Divi's. Yes the performance was weak so the stock has corrected but we are of the view that somewhere it will stabilise and will start doing pretty well.


Would you avoid any of these high PE haloed stocks -- Page, Eicher, Bosch? That is where the casualty is. Markets maybe at an all-time high but some of these stocks are at a multi-year low. How would you approach a Page, an Eicher or a Bosch or Shree Cement?Definitely because of the high valuations and the fact that we are seeing slowdown, particularly in the consumption space, the derating process may continue for a while because at the moment the entire money is chasing the set of stocks where there is a growth visibility and where you can expect quarter-on-quarter improvement in the performances.

Only a few sectors are showing signs of revival. The revival in the earnings is not visible on a broad-based basis for the next couple of quarters. I definitely think that one should avoid the stocks which have been beaten down and where you are not seeing much growth visibility. The focus should be on the banking and the financial space where there is going to be a good amount of traction a) because of the repo rate cut, liquidity infusion and because of the greater visibility because 60% of the earnings growth next year in the Nifty will come from the banking space. 


What do you make of this entire wave of buying in the PSU stocks? It reminds me of 2014 when after the NDA-1 mandate everything got re-rated.Yes, because of the underperformance and the possibility of liquidity infusion and the rate cut going ahead, the market has already started pricing that in for some of the PSU banks and yes selectively we do see State Bank of India and a couple of the large PSU banks are seeing decent amount of improvement in the operating growth, loan growth and the slippages part also has been sorted out. You might see some more upside mainly because of higher probability of rate cut but again this is not a sector where one can take one year, two year kind of a call. From a tactical opportunity perspective, there is more upside for SBI in particular.


What is going on with IndiGo? The promoter spat aside, it is a problem of restrictive choice. You only have SpiceJet and IndiGo now in the aviation space. IndiGo clearly is the leader with the largest market share. They are already guiding for a 30% increase in capacity in the next financial year.Yes absolutely. Partly because of the growth in the passenger traffic which has been pretty good in the last couple of quarters and the fact that because of the Jet saga some of these incumbent players could take a price hike so the pricing power to some extent is coming back plus operationally – a) because of the expansion on the international front and because of the expansion on the fleet per se on the neo part, there is a sense that the overall growth could be extremely good for a player like IndiGo which is extremely well placed.

They have also managed to get some more slots. The market is extremely positive there. But we have not really covered this airline sector because of the kind of volatility, news flow and sensitivity to government decision making. So yes we do appreciate the fact that IndiGo is extremely well placed but we are staying away from giving any specific recommendation for IndiGo or SpiceJet at this point of time.

Absolutely. I am more a believer of multicap approach but SIPs are always welcome. In fact, SIPs are meant to be for lean periods like this, said Gurmeet Chadha, Co-founder, Complete Circle Consultants, said in an interview with ETNOW. Edited excerpts:

Would cement and road makers be the first beneficiary of any uptick in the cycle?Absolutely. A large part of this is led by government spending and as I pointed out, that has slowed down and should probably be reflected in some of the numbers. But that is likely to pick up. 
The surplus balance with RBI is at a record high and that is likely to change. The spending will resume and if you see the manifesto of the NDA, they are talking of some obnoxious number on the infrastructure spending. I think you will probably see some massive privatisation and some other measures to reduce the fiscal stress as well. So that looks to be a safe play. 

Also in cement there are benefits in terms of reduced space cost since it is on a cost to delivery basis, the raw material cost will be benign. This year, about 27 million tonnes of additional capacity is coming in. There have been price hikes across geographies and overall on a 500- million tonne market, you have UltraTech at Rs 150. If you add ACC, Lafarge, Ambuja Group -- that will be another one-third. So, there is a lot of consolidation as well. You will now see both value and volume growth coming in this space. It may not be double digit but could be high single digits growth.


Now: What is your take on some of the auto majors?
The auto sector is not looking good with 10% production cuts for both M&M and Maruti. Also, inventory is still at 40-45 days. I have been speaking to a lot of dealers and some of them happened to be our clients. They have been sending a lot of SOS to the makers. It will take a little time before things really turnaround. M&M’s result was a bit of a mixed bag with auto segment revenue and margins holding up on back of two-three launches especially the Marazzo and the couple of the XUV300 and some of the others. 

The farm equipment side and the tractor side is where you saw the decline both in revenue as well as margins and the guidance also was a little muted. My sense is that one can gradually accumulate them on dips. The risk reward, even the downside looks limited to me because a lot of pain is in the price. M&M has seen an almost 30% price correction, as it is trading at reasonable valuations and there are not enough plays. So, there are already talks of government having an exclusive agriculture ministry. 

I was reading some data that 58% of the farm loan waivers are yet to be actioned and that will infuse a lot of rural liquidity. The RBI is maintaining cash surpluses. So, a lot of non-discretionary spending will pick up. Once liquidity returns, once the NBFC credit crunch fades away, the interest rate transmission happens, gradually it will pick up. But maybe that is one or two quarters away. Meanwhile, one can buy on dips. 

Immediately one can look at two-wheelers. Bajaj Auto looks attractive. It is gaining market share. More than 50% is due to export, there is a three-wheeler which comes in. So you can start with maybe two-wheelers first and then look at accumulating M&M and Marutis of the world on further declines.


You would not stretch your list of the private banks to Yes Bank, would you?
There are more skeletons there which are likely to come out. There is a lot of exposure to the ADAG Group. There is a significant unsecured and project finance book. You will see more provisioning in the coming two quarters. I agree the price points are pretty attractive but you can look at much better places like SBI. The consumer loan book is only 32% of the overall book. The CEO is already talking of 11-12% growth by acquiring some NBFCs portfolio. Even the private banks are being very cautious, especially when it comes to both SMEs and on corporate advances,

What CIBIL did to retail ending is what insolvency and IBC would do to corporate lending. I think there are better plays available at less than two books and we are not even discussing the recoveries which will come from the large accounts. They are at a very advanced stage. The credit cost is likely to come down, the provisioning is almost more than 70% up and you can target an increase in ROA and ROE. There are better plays and last one year ICICI and Axis have actually returned more than 50%.


Are you beginning to hunt within mid and smallcaps?
We have a more multi-cap approach, not to bias towards any particular market cap. We also have to take into account the liquidity which will chase some of the names. Globally we are already witnessing a bond rally with the US 10-year. If you remember last year, it went above 3%. We are already talking of 225-230 levels. The German and the Japanese 10-years have slipped into negative territory. We saw the Chinese PBOC yesterday infusing $36 billion through open market operations. 

I think RBI is likely to inject liquidity in the upcoming MPC on 5th and 6th of June. So, liquidity will come and once the liquidity eases, it is the front line names it will chase more. I will be happy even accumulating an ICICI Bank and I do not mind putting up an RBL Bank as well. So, I will be market cap agnostic but the mid and small cap space with both time and price correction, is not looking as wobbly as it used to be. 

There are few opportunities even in midcap space. There are some niche consumption plays which are looking very good. We saw for example TTK Prestige report very good set of numbers and the price it down more than 20%.

Is it the correct time to start SIP in a good active midcap fund for a period of three, four, five years?
Gurmeet Chadha: Absolutely. I am more a believer of multicap approach but SIPs are always welcome. In fact, SIPs are meant to be for lean periods like this and that is when you get more units. Lot of fund managers have been cherry picking. The net flows remain good. There has been Rs 8,000 odd crore kind of inflow in SIP. A large part of this comes in the small and midcap space because outperformance before the correction came, was largely in the small and midcap funds only. So liquidity courtesy SIP flows, also gives you a cushion to buy more on these declines and get the favourable price points.


What about ONGC? Any thoughts on the stock fundamentals?
 It’s an avoid for me, There are a couple of PSU names which have shown better earnings. If one has to go into PSUs with a tactical view, you are better off with Power Grid. Their work in hand bidding is almost at about Rs 18,000 crore worth of projects, their order book stands at about Rs 60,000 crore. So that looks good in light of heightened power demand. PFC grew their advances by 12-13% and I was surprised to see the cost of funds coming down by 10 bps. It seems there will be some synergy with the REC merger. If you want to play some of the PSU names, there is SBI. Being tactical is probably a better way to play. A retail investor could buy some of the PSU ETFs which keep coming which the government gives at a discount in terms of getting their privatisation and disinvestment targets in place. so That is a better way to play them.

Infrastructure is the other key flavour of the moment. Give some of the names you would look at there.
 Gurmeet Chadha: It is a broad sector. We are looking at some of the capital good makers like L&T. Last financial year, they not only met the guidance but in fact raised the guidance and if you break up the order book segment wise, it gives you further confidence. 

Their focus on giving up non-core business stays. The margins have improved. I am very positive on L&T. In fact, the stock has seen quite a nice upmove in the last couple of weeks. Cement looks very good. I am of the opinion that cement upcycle has begun. A pan-India play through UltraTech could be a good play. You can also look at some geography specific plays like Shree Cement and Ramco down south. 

So cement and maybe a couple of road makers as well.

Look into cement, two-wheelers and infra and construction as well as discretionary consumption such as appliances, food services for stocks that can double or triple, said Dipen Sheth, Head, Institutional Research, HDFC Securities, in an interview with ETNOW. Edited excerpts:


Why are markets not reacting to sub 7% bond yields?I wish I was a macroeconomist. God knows, I am struggling as an analyst and so yes, it is a little bit of a conundrum. It reflects sluggishness in the economy and weak demand more than anything else. I guess that would more or less explain it. I do not have a great macroeconomic reason to justify this and we are probably sitting on upcoming fiscal slippage. 

If the government has to rev up the economy through fiscal boost, for example, by reducing taxes on basic consumption things like cement and boosting rural spend through reduction of GST on two- wheelers, a lot of that would add up to expanding the fiscal deficit. I do not see why bond yields should fall. One big reason why they could be falling is also having more confidence in the ability of reforms. Divestment could be the big lever here and it is not small bits of inconsequential PSUs which might come up but it could be the big whammy, the oil marketing companies, Air India etc. There could be a whole lot of government presence in sectors and industries where it should not be. Those could be up for sale for all I know.

I am not saying and these are my prescriptions for the government. I am not saying we are likely to do it but rather that there is a whole lot of possibilities.


Woes seem to be continuing for the auto sector. -- be it elections, tight liquidity. But a lot of companies are saying that the new government’s measures to revive the economy are likely to rev up the overall auto space. The numbers have been a big disappointment. Do you think that after three consecutive month of fall that now we are seeing light at the end of the tunnel?Let me give you a slightly a long complicated answer to what sounds like a simple question from you. First, we need to understand that autos is end of the day a cyclical space and we were sitting on two-three good years of numbers across the space. So some of that had to give. The second thing is that incremental auto demand is coming in mostly from upcountry markets. The metros are getting saturated. There is ride-share coming in, there is driving difficulty and a lot of millennials do not want to buy cars or even bikes anymore. They would much rather use an Uber or Ola. 

Incremental demand was coming in from upcountry areas and those were the areas which have been in economic pain for quite some time. There have been three soft monsoons and if this one is also going to be soft, then there is serious trouble coming up. Although the government has a whole lot of levers, it is very creditable that agricultural output has held up despite indifferent monsoons but that is a different story. 

Third, unless IIP and manufacturing rev up, I do not think there is a hope in hell that CVs will revive anytime soon. There is also an emission norm change coming up. We will see a little bit of pre-buying happening in Q2-Q3 but I do not think there is a structural case for arguing a bull run in CVs over the next three-four years, especially with the DFC coming up not just the Delhi Mumbai but the eastern DFC also.

I do not think CVs are going to be part of the auto revival as and when that happens, cars are of course consumer discretionary, people can postpone demand a little bit of bunching up will happen may be in a year out from now so that should be good for brand leaders like Maruti as you can see that the not so strong brands like Tata’s have suffered much more in this crack. 

On two-wheelers, I have a completely different point of view. We are probably sitting on a very sweet value zone for two-wheelers -- be it Hero or Bajaj, which are the two largest listed players in the space. 

I cannot understand why a pragmatic government would continue to have 28% GST on entry level two-wheelers. You can have a higher GST for Enfield bikes but why for a 110-cc bikes or even for that matter a 150-cc bike? If that was brought down to 18%, then I would see very good times for two-wheelers. Both these companies are very high, ROIC companies, Bajaj has actually pumped up volumes over the last year. Hero has struggled but the next two or three years look very interesting for both of these guys.


 The challenge for Bajaj could be that the three-wheeler business, not the two-wheeler business. The three-wheeler business is slowing down and that was the cash cow. For Hero MotoCorp, the challenge is that they have nothing in exports while for Bajaj, export is a fillip. There should be a longer view on three-wheelers. Remember Bajaj has got into the freight end of the three-wheeler market, not just the passenger end and it has been doing very well there. God knows, people like Greaves and Atul have been hit by what Bajaj has achieved. They obviously have a very strong distribution network. On the passenger end of the three- wheeler market, I do not think we have seen the end of it so far. It is a phenomenally high margin business for Bajaj but it is not that the other parts of the portfolio are not making money. 

Having said that, even the passenger three-wheeler market is likely to take off in case of a penetration and urbanisation-led pull for passenger three-wheelers increases in up market India. Maybe you do not have too much of scope for selling passenger three-wheelers in Mumbai or Pune or Delhi, but surely it would be there in Aurangabad. Some of that will play out increasingly as government spend and urbanisation in tier II and tier III India play out. A lot of three-wheeler demand will actually play out over the next few years.

I am not too worried about that part of their portfolio. What people have been worried about on Bajaj is whether they are discounting their way into the entry-level segment in a bit to get volumes all over again. That has played out and they have held their horses there after an initial burst to get their volumes. Bajaj now has a much more balanced portfolio mix. The big gaping hole in scooters continues to bug me.

On Hero, the relevant thing to note is the fact that they have now got into the mid premium segment where they were virtually not present for a long time and remember the up selling to the staple hero crowd in mid tier India is likely to happen with these models as well as increase in presence in the metros. I am not worried on these two companies at all. A little bit of a push from the government in the form of reduced GST -- perhaps it is aspirational but it is likely that a pragmatic and sensible government would figure out that taxing things like two-wheelers and cement at this point of time at 28% just does not make sense.


Do you think a rate cut is imperative as otherwise, the market would open up some serious downside since it seems to have factored in a 50 bps rate cut on June 6?If you are stuck with a sluggish economy and low inflation, there is very little that rbi can do on the monetary front except for pushing for a rate cut. I would agree that 25 bps is a virtual given at this point of time. They may not engage in heroics and do 50 bps for the simple reason that there is uncertainty in oil. 

But, apart from monetary stimulus, fiscal stimulus and as we have said recently in our note on Modi 2.0, policy stimulus is the big hurdle that India has to go through. Since this government has now got a clean mandate for a fresh five-year term, this is the time to do big and bold things, a little bit of fiscal slippage, a little bit of monetary loosening -- much as it may sound Keynesian to lots of classical economists -- will be forgiven at this stage in Modi 2.0. 

This is something that Modi 1.0 should have done very early in the game. They did try doing much of this but it was getting a little late. Right now, monetary stimulus from the RBI, fiscal stimulus from the government and most important a fat reform agenda from Modi 2.0, big bold aggressive reforms that can completely change the character of the nation and not just three months trajectory is called for.


Give me one infra space where you are convinced things will change for better and structurally and cyclically these are stocks which can be potentially double or even 3x in this NDA-2 regime?Let us start by eliminating, the global cyclicals are certainly not going to make me that kind of money -- be it the steel stocks or the non steel metals. They are affected through global cycles which frankly are difficult to predict sitting out of India. So let us rule them out. 

Local cyclicals - cement as well as two-wheelers -- are set for policy-led revival and increasing consumption and penetration especially in upcountry India, the natural beneficiaries of a revival in cement. Cement pricing has been very strong in Q4 last year. It continues to be extremely strong in Q1 and I salivate to think what might happen to cement company profits should GST be brought down from 28%. The natural proxies there would obviously be UltraTech in the largecap space and maybe Shree Cement. Something like Dalmia has been very consistent in profitability; a Birla Corp which is probably the cheapest 15 million ton cement company available in India at this point of time, a Ramco which is also not cheap might make sense in that cycle. 

And of course, Hero and Bajaj in the two-wheeler space where I have already outlined my arguments. Another year out from now, maybe if we see a revival in discretionary spending, then maybe four-wheelers can also take off and Maruti can turn out to be a very interesting buy. But that’s about it. If you look outside these two sectors, then infra and construction, are the two sectors given the appetite of this government to spend and to drive infrastructure spend.

The old anchor L&T is running up, I do not know whether it is a doubler or tripler in three years but it is a very good proxy for playing the revival in infra spend on a broader base. You will never be as comfortable with L&T’s valuations as you might be with some of the small cap stocks but remember that all the midcaps and smallcaps in the sector added up, do not quite add up to L&T’s market cap or its Nifty weight for that matter.

L&T is going to be an anchor in any portfolio which is aligned with Modi 2.0. But other than L&T we like names like KNR Constructions and PNB Infratech, fat order books, very clean balance sheets, particularly in the case of KNR they are still sub 50 days. In terms of networking capital cycle, both are excellently managed companies. The fat order book is now going to come into play over the next few years. So, infra and construction, the local consumption themes argument might also be interesting.

I am not just talking about the 40-50 PE kind of FMCG stocks but discretionary consumption such as appliances, food service. So food service, naturally Jubilant Food Works despite high valuations continues to be one of our top picks. On the appliances space, we are seeing a scorching summer now finally playing out and you have seen the run up in stocks like Symphony despite an average quarter. Voltas is set for a good time despite what people see as a bad quarter in terms of the slippage in its core business segment margins.

These are a couple of names and of course, V-Guard which is now building a north India franchise very aggressively and much of its one-time spends on advertising and brand promotion seem to be in the base. V-Guard is also set for a couple of very good years.

NEW DELHI: Most cement stocks were trading in the red in Tuesday's afternoon session.

Shares of SKCIL (down 4.94 per cent), Barak Valley Cements (down 4.86 per cent), India Cements (down 4.75 per cent), Ambuja Cements (down 4.14 per cent), ACC (down 4.04 per cent), APCL (down 3.80 per cent), Udaipur Cement Works (down 3.68 per cent), Deccan Cements (down 3.20 per cent), HIL (down 3.11 per cent) and Shree Digvijay Cement Co (down 3.05 per cent) plunged up to 5 per cent.

Sanghi Industries (down 2.89 per cent), Prism Johnson (down 2.87 per cent), NCL Industries (down 2.86 per cent), Shree Cement (down 2.71 per cent), GPT Infraprojects (down 2.38 per cent), Shiva Cement (down 2.21 per cent), Andhra Cements (down 2.20 per cent), The Ramco Cements Ltd (down 2.15 per cent), IFGL Refractories (down 2.13 per cent), Burnpur Cement (down 2.08 per cent), Sagar Cements (down 1.89 per cent), K C P (down 1.82 per cent), UltraTech Cement (down 1.38 per cent), Orient Refractories (down 1.38 per cent) and Birla Corporation (down 1.33 per cent) too were trading with losses. 

Meanwhile, Keerthi Industries (up 4.75 per cent), Visaka Industries (up 2.19 per cent), HeidelbergCement India (up 1.93 per cent), Rain Industries Ltd (up 1.24 per cent) and Sahyadri Industries (up 1.10 per cent) were trading higher.

The NSE Nifty50 index was trading 37.95 points down at 12,050.60 while the 30share BSE Sensex was down 75.94 points at 40,191.68 at around 02:25 pm. 

NTPC (up 1.99 per cent), Bharti Infratel (up 1.88 per cent), Axis Bank (up 1.50 per cent), YES Bank (up 1.47 per cent) and Vedanta (up 1.22 per cent) were among the top gainers in the Nifty pack. 

On the other hand, Zee Entertainment Enterprises (down 2.95 per cent), Hero MotoCorp (down 2.86 per cent), Asian Paints (down 2.64 per cent), Dr. Reddy's Laboratories (down 2.35 per cent) and HCL Technologies (down 2.25 per cent) were trading in the red.


Bull or Bear? Stay on top of the game with our LIVE MARKET BLOG

India’s cement industry, the second-biggest in the world, is set to cement its pricing power locally after a prolonged phase of capacity overhang that had prevented previous attempts at increasing realisations.

Last fiscal year was favourable for the cement industry for several reasons. First, the industry clocked double-digit volume growth for the first time in the past nine years. Second, even capacity utilisation, which reached close to 71%, improved 5% on year — the highest in the past seven years. Third, cement prices climbed about 2% in FY19. Fuel costs also declined, in lockstep with crude prices.

This year, the industry is expected to build on the achievements of FY19 and enhance realisations, by 2-5%. Infrastructure investments by the government should aid that effort. In each of the next five years, the Central government is expected to build about 6,000 km length of roads. Besides this, the low-cost housing segment is also likely to boost cement demand. Analysts point out that the government’s investments in infrastructure and its focus on the pace of execution should help sustain cement prices within a favourable range.


Sustainability of cement prices would determine the attractiveness of cement stocks. Given the present situation, companies in the northern, central, and eastern regions are likely to show better revenue growth for FY20. UltraTech Cement, Shree Cement, Ramco, JK Lakshmi Cement, and Orient Cement are expected to report higher realisations of at least 4% in FY20.

In the past four months, cement stocks are up in the range of 35-40% and trading at premium valuation to historical averages. Premium valuations are expected to be undergirded by expectations of higher volumes and realisations in FY20.

Shares of Birla Corporation (down 6.64 per cent), JK Lakshmi Cement (down 6.61 per cent), APCL (down 5.63 per cent), SKCIL (down 4.98 per cent), NCL Industries (down 4.92 per cent), Sagar Cements (down 4.86 per cent), Prism Johnson (down 4.76 per cent), Sanghi Industries (down 4.34 per cent), India Cements (down 4.27 per cent), Orient Cement Ltd (down 3.74 per cent), HIL (down 3.63 per cent), ACC (down 3.63 per cent), Everest Industries (down 3.48 per cent), Rain Industries Ltd (down 3.39 per cent), Dalmia Bharat (down 3.37 per cent), Mangalam Cement (down 3.26 per cent), Deccan Cements (down 3.20 per cent) and UltraTech Cement (down 3.11 per cent) plunged up to 7 per cent.

Bigbloc Construction (down 2.94 per cent), Andhra Cements (down 2.85 per cent), HeidelbergCement India (down 2.82 per cent), Ambuja Cements (down 2.75 per cent), Sahyadri Industries (down 2.74 per cent), J K Cements (down 2.56 per cent), Saurashtra Cement (down 2.54 per cent), Shiva Cement (down 2.47 per cent), Shree Digvijay Cement (down 2.19 per cent), Keerthi Industries (down 2.14 per cent), Shree Cement (down 2.14 per cent), Ramco Industries (down 1.95 per cent), Kakatiya Cements Sugar & Industries (down 1.83 per cent), The Ramco Cements Ltd (down 1.79 per cent), Gujarat Sidhee Cement (down 1.66 per cent), Visaka Industries (down 1.41 per cent), IFGL Refractories (down 1.41 per cent) and Morganite Crucible (India) (down 1.20 per cent) too were trading with losses. 

Meanwhile, Star Cement (up 4.25 per cent), Barak Valley Cements (up 1.70 per cent), Orient Refractories (up 1.04 per cent), K C P (up 0.62 per cent) and Udaipur Cement Works (up 0.32 per cent) were trading higher.
