On the other hand, GAIL (India) (down 10.45 per cent), Indiabulls Housing Finance (down 8.26 per cent), IndusInd Bank (down 7.28 per cent), YES Bank (down 5.92 per cent) and State Bank of India (down 3.75 per cent) were trading in the red.

Future of cement demand is dependent on how GDP grows and I am really confident that GDP will be growing by 7% to 7.5%. So, cement demand will be growing at almost the same range, 1% up or down, said HM Bangur, MD, Shree Cement, in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts:

In the area which you represent, north and parts of central India, is demand significantly better or is still thanda?Demand is a little better, not significantly better nor thanda. Cement demand sporadically can go up or down, but overall it will go now if the GDP is up by 7%. The demand will go up by 6% to 8%. It is a very good correlation with GDP. So nothing unusual. Three-year GDP growth and three-year demand growth will be almost equal.


Do you think demand will remain firm and is there a genuine uptick both in industrial and consumption or could the monsoon have a deterrent?Monsoon comes every year. When we say demand, you have to compare August to August, September to September. Monsoon factor is not important. Monsoon will be important if you compare April-June to July-September but that is not comparable. Secondly, the future of cement demand is totally dependent on how GDP grows and I am really confident that GDP will be growing by 7% to 7.5%. So, cement demand will be growing at almost the same range, 1% up or down. 


What about pricing? There has been some indications from the regulator on that front. Given the recent spike in prices, they are not exactly happy with it. You have also said that you are going to be focussing on pricing going forward. What kind of trends do you first see and for Shree Cement what is the agenda?Year after year, the average price rise of the year will be 3% to 3.5%, much lower than the inflation. This has been the trend of price rise for last many years and now also. When yearly price rise is 3%, sometimes it is negative, sometimes it goes up 10%. But overall, year to year, it will be 3% or so. This has been the trend for the last 10 years. Only when the price rise is there, we talk about it. But when the price falls, everybody keeps quiet. But overall, the cement price in the year will not be going up more than 3% to 4% maximum compared to last year. This has been a trend for so many years and it will continue.


Typically ahead of election, cement demand always goes down. I am not surprised that in April and May, there has been contraction in some parts of India. Would demand come back and in which parts of India, is demand elasticity still the highest?At the time of election, there will always be a shortage of labour. Temporarily, the demand comes down. But it will go up and the demand will be dependant totally on GDP growth because when GDP grows, everything is needed. Company has the need along with its capacity to pay and when both matches, then only demand comes. 

Capacity and production in any commodity capacity will be much higher than production. Indian cement industry is capable of meeting the needs of the country and they have created the demand. They have created the capacity a little earlier than demand. We are at least three years ahead and our project capacity can serve demand even after two years with 15% growth or so. That can be served easily. There will not be any shortage of cement in the country.


What is the status of your new plant in south India and what kind of capacities is it running at?I have just put a new plant in south India. We are starting there with the right price and it is running at a very low capacity at present. We are making our brand there and significant capacity will be coming by the end of the year. For the first six months, we have run with very low capacity. It is continuously increasing and depending on the market scenario, it will definitely go up. Our capacity utilisation will become far better. 


What is the new innovation which is coming from Shree Cement? Also what exactly is your cement realisation right now?The focus is on providing better quality cement. The Indian market has become mature and can absorb better quality. Our focus is that between us and the highest selling brands, the difference should come down. We are working on it. For the time being, our focus is on maintaining the cost and improving the quality. Cost cutting again is now no more there. We are trying to improve the quality and that will be our focus. And when we improve the quality, naturally the brand has to go up. The marketing price has to go up. We are increasing our prices in all markets.


Are you facing any clinker shortage and how is your Middle East market gearing up? Are you seeing any revival or pickup in the middle eastern region?We do not feel any clinker shortage in north India. We should be able to meet the total demand of north whatever it comes. The second question about Middle East market is slow but fortunately our plant is just on the port and the whole world is a market for us as shipping facility is very good. We are exporting and getting our revenue in Middle East. The Middle East slowdown is hardly affecting us.


You are moving more towards branded segment. You are targeting largely small builders and home builders. Considering where real estate prices are moving and the HFC segment is under pressure, don’t you think this could be a dangerous strategy?It is a very long-term strategy. In 10 years or so, we expect the Indian market will revive and when we are moving towards that, it will take us some time, the brand building, the confidence in the market comes very slowly and we are moving in the right direction. We have introduced two new brands of premium brands and the response is good.


Could you share with us in dollar terms, the enterprise value (EV) per ton that you are looking at from that plant? Secondly going forward, could you share with us your debt cash flow (DCF)?Our is a debt-free company. So, the whole question of discounted cash flow and DCF is not very meaningful for us. Cash flow will come very gradually. You will have to keep the plant running; bear some losses for the first or second year. I has to be supported by other operations. Once the manufacturing matures, the market matures, then also a small profit starts trickling in and maybe after three years, it will mature fully.


Markets look at the enterprise value of cement companies. You do not have a debt but what is the enterprise value or EV per ton you would ascribe to a new capacity like Shree Cement if it has to get created? In the next 12 to18 months, what will be your total installed capacity and the capacity utilisation there?First part, I am the least entitled to say about it. It is for analysts to say. They have to think what capacity and what value and what other things, there are many complex metrics. We know manufacturing and we do the right thing. Markets value us, we do not value ourselves. In two years time, we will be around 50 million tons.


What will be your total installed capacity and on an aggregate basis, where do you see your utilisation rate settling for the entire capacity?Our total capacity is around 45 million tons now and in two years time, it will be 50 million tons and we will be running at 70% or so.


Where do you think the biggest challenge lies for the cement sector and for Shree Cement?The cement sector is totally dependent on major economic growth which I am very confident about. There would not be much problem as far as the cement is concerned. Secondly, the public have money. There is enough need of cement in India. Now with the growth in per capita income, the need is being converted into demand as money is available. 

I do not think any major problem is there and Indian cement prices are low compared to world prices. In most of the places, the prices are high and the turnover to capital ratio is very low. Our turnover will be around 30% of the capital cost. All the money has to come from that 30% turnover to service the capital.


In the last 10 years, the stock is up nearly 9x. That must be making you happy? As a promoter I am sure it is a satisfactory moment?Of course, it is and I am very happy that the market and shareholders’ value and have faith in the company. We are performing and we will be performing as we were performing before, nothing special has to be done. Some fiscal discipline and a lot of innovation has to be done on a daily basis.

Earnings growth being restricted to only few sectors has restricted the scope for new investment ideas across market capitalisations. The difficulties are compounded by the not-so-encouraging improvement in private capital expenditure in recent years. In such a situation, it makes sense to focus on large-sized companies, which offer stability to the portfolio. 

Dominant market share, high return ratios, steady cash flows, consistent dividend paying record and relatively better balance sheets ensure consistency in earnings. For conservative investors, these factors are important as they ensure that share prices of large-sized companies is not as volatile as mid and small-sized companies. 

Among large-cap schemes, investors can consider SBI Bluechip with an investment horizon of at least five years. A key characteristic of the scheme is that it stays away from momentum stocks and focuses on themes which do well only in the long-term. 

Besides its low expense ratio, the scheme’s fund manager Sohini Andani has been focusing on companies that have certain distinct advantage even among large-sized companies. For instance, Andani has invested in Shree Cement due to its cost efficiency even if it is not the largest cement manufacturer. 

In the past five-year and ten-year periods, the scheme has given 13% and 12% returns, respectively while peers in the same category have given average returns of 10% and 11% returns, respectively.

Expert Take

Harshvardhan Roongta,CFP, Roongta Securities
The scheme follows a combination of value and growth style of investing. Its conservative investment decisions has led to its under performance during sustained bull runs when compared to its peers and benchmarks in the recent past. However, it has been an outperformer over longer periods of time when markets complete two to three cycles.

In the Indian context, it is a win-win situation and despite pessimism, I do not rule out 12,200 coming before the budget, says Sanjiv Bhasin, Executive Vice President, IIFL Securities, in an interview with ETNOW. Edited excerpts:

Could Reliance signing this term sheet with Brookfield as reported by The Economic Times be a material and sizable positive considering the valuation at $15 billion? We are talking about almost halving the debt on their books?Finally, the sun is shining for Reliance. First, came the Saudi Aramco deal for selling part of their energy assets and now they are trying to monetise the Jio towers. It is a very big positive in the sense that Reliance is now going to try and become a lean mean fighting machine in the sense they realise that they are slowly transitioning into a technology company and there is going to be a huge capex involved there. Slowly but surely, they are trying to get the financialisations on the right path and I see no let up in this. 

Reliance is truly on its way to becoming a Rs 10-lakh-crore market cap company in the next one year. All declines should be used to buy. We have a one-year target of Rs 1,500. Its underperformance in the recent months may start to see an uptick again in Reliance, given that both the monetisation on the spectrum side and on the energy side is on the cards in the next six months.


What is happening in crude on the back of the OMCs cooling off yesterday? ONGC was showing a lot of strength. Overall, it is going to be positive for India but on the back of the trend that we are currently seeing, if crude were to continue to cool off, would you be taking a closer look at some of the names impacted by that?We have had a contrarian view on most of the OMC. They have smartly rewarded in the last four months. I still think HP, BP, IOC are wonderful businesses and if crude is going to be a tailwind, now with prices slowly but surely drifting below $60, it is a win-win situation. 

Also along with that, look at the strength in the rupee. We think that free pricing has been extremely positive for them. There will be regular bouts of profit booking but we still think there is a 20% upside even after such a sharp run-up in some of the OMCs. We are also very positive on select gas utilities and IGL, MGL on decline remain our top pick. 

We think the selloff in GAIL may be overdone. Even with a 4% rise in PNGRB pricing, they can still give a 10% CAGR over the next two years cum bonus. At Rs 300, GAIL also becomes an attractive buy. So, OMCs, gas utilities all are in a very very sweet spot right now.


Would you look deeper into IT, perhaps into some of the midcap names?The rupee which was a tailwind, is now a headwind and globally the environment for IT and BFSI space is not all that alluring. We want to play the India story given the budget and the underperformance of PSUs. We think alpha will really be created by cement, construction, infrastructure. In the short run, the volatility and protection of capital will be seen by IT given it has been a bellwether. 

If I can take two names, it would be TCS and HCL Tech. HCL Tech has moved up very sharply from those Rs 950 levels to Rs 1,120 but we still think that it is the best executor on the BFSI space. TCS itself has become a prima donna. It has become the largest market cap. If you want to be in these stocks, these two merit ownership. However, any pullback now in the rally at above 12,000, it will be the broader market which will lead and IT may tend to become a market performer to slight underperformer going ahead. 


What is your perspective on DHFL? They have managed to avert the defaulter tag after making that due payment of Rs 960 odd crore to NCDs. Does that make them worthy of investment? You know where the problem is. We have still not filled the void created by IL&FS. The short term commercial borrowing is still in a limbo and the competitors have gained because of some of these errant promoters. Over-leverage is not a bad word but if you had a very good run in the last five years, adequate checks and balances should have been on the cards for the likes of Indiabulls or DHFL or Zee. 

ADAG came and clarified. Words will not materially change it. You got to show the money on the table. We think there are enough other plays which are going to make up for that and already corporate banks are in the best of shape as they take on the loan portfolios of most of these debt saddled players. So ICICI, Axis, SBI would be the key over there. 

Among housing finance companies, it will continue to be Bajaj Finance. LIC Housing Finance can be further rerated, given its pedigree performance and now the book size is increasing with NIMs also expanding. The other two would be Cholamandalam and HDFC if you want to stick with the top names. As a trading bounce, DHFL definitely could see some rearguard actions. You could see the stock maybe trading towards Rs 120 in the next three to four months. 


The next big trigger would only come from the budget. How big an event could it turn out to be from an equity market standpoint?Before the budget, you have Trump and Xi meeting at the G-20. If anything, the Dow has seen the best rally in the last one year in June. The Dow is up 1,600 points in the last 10 days on the back of Mexico sanctions getting averted. We will have to keep our fingers crossed that Trump does not wake up on the wrong side on the 29th and if you have a deal, then that will actually set the cat amongst the pigeons. In the last fortnight, global markets have been rallying sharply, given that the dollar is at a three-month low; the carry trade is up and running; also the Fed is going to cut rates. 

In the Indian context, you have one of the best budgets on the anvil given the strong mandate and given the macros have been very positive for the government. They can instil a lot of confidence through liquidity and sort out some of the imbroglio on consumption. It is a win-win situation and despite the pessimism we are closer to 12,000. I do not rule out 12,200 coming before the budget.


You were so bullish with regards to the domestic story, the capital goods story, infra. Let us talk about some of the names that you are looking at in that basket. Would you also go in for higher risk names?We think cement, construction, capex, corporate banks are going to lead from the front. In banks we like ICICI, Axis, SBI; in the smaller banks we are very bullish on DCB, Federal Bank, IDFC First. In cement it is UltraTech, ACC and Shree Cement as they have been able to expand margins during a lean season. Once you are through with monsoons, cement will be an outperforming sector in the next one year. 

Construction picks would be again NBCC, Nagarjuna where a lot of weakness has crept in because of some change of government. It is just temporary. Sadbhav Engineering over is another top pick. In capex, it is L&T, Siemens, ABB, pedigree names which are going to get a huge order flow which show that books are swelling and execution is the name of the game. 

We know that the government capex has been in the front running and now private capex is going to be the next game changer. For the next 12 to 18 months, the stocks should be India centric and they can generate a lot of wealth going forward.

OMCs are value stocks one should consider buying, says Sameer Narayan, Market Expert, in an interview with ETNOW. Edited excerpts:


Are the internals looking alright or do you think liquidity is still the biggest concern that is going to continue to plague us? Liquidity at the margin is improving because the RBI stance has also altered. It is also a question of the demand for liquidity. For businesses to take more credit, they have to be confident about the kind of sales or revenues that will happen in the near future. They would probably look at doing a capex or taking on further loans or debt only when they see some amount of buoyancy. 

In the near term, monsoon and Budget could be the big drivers. The budget in terms of the policy statement and the monsoon in terms of the sentiment. 


Do you see another rate cut by the central bank as something the market will start to factor in as a positive or is it still waiting for some other cues?In terms of a rate cut, the central bank has always been mentioning that they are bothered about the transmission aspect. Now there is actually a headwind there because today the combined fiscal deficit of both the state governments and the centre is close to 6-6.5%. That is a ceiling which gives you very little room for a 50 or 70 or 100 bps rate cut. Unless it gets transmitted, you will not see the cost of funding for an average business going down. We clearly have a challenge there.


Do you still have conviction that perhaps things will improve for some of the higher beta names going forward?One has to dissect it in two ways. The way it works is there is one section of the market where growth is probably more than adequately priced in. One needs to drill down in these sectors where perhaps the room for disappointment is less because you are not actually paying for it. So utilities, oil marketing company, or capital goods are the sectors where perhaps the expectations are low. Therefore, there is a probability of some positive earnings and that could then give you a room for valuations to trend up.

We have seen for the last three years that you start with expected earnings growth at 25-24% and then as the year goes by, you keep scaling it down. What has actually led to is perhaps only multiple expansion and now we need to really see the earnings kick in because if you remove the corporate banks apart, there is very little in terms of the profit pool for us to start valuing.


But how soon do you see the profit pool expanding to utilities to capital goods etc.Nobody is good at timing the market. But the way the Prime Minister has outlined his priority, probably the market participants need to figure out what is that he needs to be looking at when he talks about ease of living. That has a lot of connotations for may be urban infra, the whole sanitation aspect and probably these are places where up till now private sector could invest only in a limited way. So chances are that in case there are some real policy making initiatives in the budget, the private sector would be allowed entry into the sectors that could probably unleash the animal spirits.


D-Mart, Page, Bosch, Shree Cement used to be the go-to stocks for every fund manager. With the valuation and the return on equity some of these companies give, those who bought these stocks made money. Are these stocks after a 15-20% correction giving a good entry point?No company is in a perpetual growth mode. You have companies which are in growth phases. The first leg of the above trend growth is already captured, delivered and priced. Unless and until visibility improves on the next growth leg which may not be a 20% CAGR over the next three years, but even a 15% growth should do.


Let me propose a template -- buy a company which has a little bit of moat around it and has got good promise in terms of return ratios. It may not be the cheapest stock in the town but it can still be a 15% to 20% earnings compounder. What would you buy?One should look at oil marketing companies.


So you will buy OMCs for next three years and you buy them today?Absolutely.


You buy them today?Absolutely.


Will you buy them after the show, have you already bought them?Well of course I mean these are the value stocks that one should look at today.


In last seven days, first it was Deloitte, then it was PwC. I hear other auditors are also under the scanner right now. Is it like saying that auditors have closed their eyes to the reality of some of the corporate balance sheets and that is terrible news?
A good way to look at it is that now things are changing because if one understands, this is what was happening for the last five years. Today they are waking up and then asking questions. At least now we are coming close to the turn.


But the change will come with pain!Absolutely.


And the pain is going to be felt before the change happens.No doubt.


Are markets prepared for this pain?Frankly. in certain pockets I do not think so at all because though pricing growth expectation of 25% book growth has now come down to 10-15%, one would really need to wonder what exactly is the composition of the book.


Should one pay greater importance to the global poor macros, fear of a slowdown, contraction in bond yields or the local macros where there is oil currency and bond yields all on the same side?
India has a problem on the global macros because for 14 years, our percentage exports to GDP has remained flat which for a country of our size is honestly a matter of concern. If you drill it down further, the large employment generating sectors -- be it leather, textiles, agri -- all of them have just not taken off. So, quite honestly these are things that we need to fix. In India, product markets have seen quite a lot of reforms but it is the factor market that now needs to be put in place. Then people to come and take a bet on investment.


The Indiabulls management is clarifying that you cannot take a complaint from a shareholder who has got four shares! Seriously, the stock is down about 10% in two days?But the fact is that it has retraced also if you look at the two weeks prior to that, it also retraced quite a bit. These kind of volatile moves one probably needs to look at it over a longish period of time.


A move in Indiabulls risk or volatility? But is the current price action in Indiabulls telling you a risk is coming or is this a volatility which an investor should use to buy?I think volatility comes only when risk is around the corner.


So are you saying the move is risky?Absolutely.


You will not buy the stock?Definitely not.


What will you buy then where there is perceived volatility but you do not think that is a risk?
There is enough value in say the lenders who today are looking at assets that are available to pick and choose. The NBFCs had flooded the market over the last half a decade. Today you are saying the PSU banks are coming back. The assets are available. They are locking in good yields and the challenge for them is that today the L/D ratio is almost tallying off and they also need some amount of good credit borrowers for them to start going in for long growth. 

Today you are not pricing in the delta in most of the PSU banks. But for those PSU banks, for example SBI, the results were very encouraging. It is the largest lender in the country. One needs to see where you are not pricing in the expected change where the rate of change has already been priced. The room for disappointment can be huge and that is why volatility happens.

MUMBAI: In line with its strategy to invest in Indian real estate, American private equity major Blackstone has struck agreed to buy nearly 0.7 million sqft of office space in One BKC from the city-based developer Radius, for a reported Rs 2,500 crore, making it the largest deal in the country's office space.

With around USD 10.4 billion investments in the country since 2005, Blackstone is the largest global investor in the domestic realty market with an exposure of over USD 5.4 billion and the One BKC deal is the largest in the office space segment to date.

While Radius has confirmed the deal with Blackstone, it refused to divulge details including valuation.

Blackstone has been pumping money across sector and of the total investment, USD 6.6 billion were pumped in the past four years alone.

Its real estate division has so far committed nearly USD 5.4 billion across 33 investments in the country, of which it has committed USD 4 billion towards acquiring Grade A commercial office buildings and invested the rest in retail, hotel and residential assets.

In April, Blackstone announced its plans to acquire a majority stake in packaging company Essel Propack for Rs 3,211 crore, and in February it bought 97.7 percent stake in Aadhar Housing Finance by buying out Wadhawan Global Capital and DHFL for Rs 3,000 crore.

And in May, Blackstone along with its partner Embassy has also launched the country's first real estate investment trust 'Embassy Office Parks REIT', which raised Rs 3000 crore.

Besides the Embassy Group, Blackstone has also partnered with developers like Salarpuria Sattva Group, Indiabulls Real Estate, Panchshil Realty, and K Raheja Corp, among others.

Under the present deal with Radius, Blackstone has agreed to buy nearly 7 lakh sqft of space at One BKC, the most sought after central business district in the megapolis. The property has around 1.5 million sqft and Blackstone is snapping up nearly half of the built-up space, making it the largest office space deal in the country to date.

Spread across 2.5 acres, One BKC houses many leading names such as Bank of America, Trafigura, Cisco, Facebook, Amazon, ICBC, Shree Cement, Motherson Sumi, Hitachi and ICICI Prudential, among others.

As per reports, Radius will use the proceeds from the deal to repay Rs 1,600 crore it has taken from Indiabulls Housing Finance for the project.

Brokerages remain cautious on the cement sector as price increases that began in April have failed to sustain.

Sluggish demand and the onset of monsoons suggest price moderation should continue and margins could peak near term in the June quarter.

Cement prices in June 2019 have corrected by 2 per cent or Rs 7 per kg, reversing the increase in May.

While Ambuja Cement and ACC declined 5 per cent each in the past month, UltraTech gained just a percent. The other two cement majors such as Shree Cement and Grasim gained 5 per cent and 6 per cent, respectively.

“We see June quarter cement prices and margins at near-term peak and expect price moderation to continue,” said Sumangal Nevatia, analyst, Kotak Securities. “We believe large capacity addition will keep industry utilisations low over the next two years and will restrict sustainable improvement in margins.”

Companies such as ACC, Ambuja Cement and Grasim are currently trading 12 times their FY20 estimated EV/EBITDA. Shree Cement and UltraTech Cement are trading at 16 times. “We maintain a cautious stance on the cement sector on expensive valuations of large-cap cement names at 12-16 times FY21 estimated EV/EBITDA,” said Nevatia.

Analysts believe that steep increases in cement prices are not sustainable and there could be a decline once the demand from non-trade segment improves.



“Although cement prices have not seen much of a correction in North, demand has taken a knock and this remains a cause for concern,” said Sanjeev Kumar Singh, analyst, Emkay. “Most (dealers) expect some decline in cement prices going forward and some of them believe average price increase in FY20 should be limited to 3-4 per cent year-on-year”.

Sales volumes for the industry has seen a steep decline after March 2019.

In April the decline was 3.2 per cent yearon-year and 14.9 in May. Volumes for June are expected to fall by14-17 per cent year-on-year. This seems to be driven by higher spending during the pre-election period, unavailability of labour and surging temperatures. Industry experts, however, believe that the liquidity crunch has had a greater impact in causing demand to soften.

By Chandan Taparia

Motherson Sumi, Apollo Tyres and Exide among midcaps and BHEL among largecaps are the stocks where 5-7% of portfolio can be allocated now, says Sanjiv Bhasin, Executive Vice President, IIFL Securities. Excerpts from his interview with ETNOW.


There is no large fear visible both locally and globally. Yet, gold prices are up 10% in last one month. Is the bullion market telling you something which we cannot see today because markets are forward looking and tend to capture the events well ahead of its occurrence?Donald Trump’s tweets on the Federal Reserve are playing out and we think that yields are going to head below 2%. It also means a 50 bps and may be more rate cut coming in the US. This means the dollar is at a three-month low and can get weaker. Not buying the euro because of the weakness of prolonged quantitative easing and so gold becomes a good destination. Also, it shows you that the risk-on trade globally is there with the emerging markets outperforming to hit a new high. 

In the Indian context it cannot be more bullish because there are no buyers, there are only people lining up for selling.This time gold is not going to be for fancy buying. It should be a sellers’ market. In fact people will liquidate gold and get back into SIPs which is the new gold for the longer term. People’s fancy for gold is now abating and I can only see sellers who are going to encash that and may be plough back part of it into SIPs. I remain extremely bullish on Indian equities and globally the easy liquidity is going to see much more of a risk-on trade for the next part of the year.


What is your go-to stock right now from the midcap space where a 20-30% move is coming in the next 12 months and where you are ready to allocate 5-7% of your portfolio?There are two sectors. OEMs have bottomed out before the auto sector. Three stocks which were taken to the cleaners, are now seeing a lot of revival. These are Motherson Sumi, Apollo Tyres and Exide. They can be huge wealth creators given that the festive season in the next three months and some initiative from the government will be a key game changer. 

The other one would be definitely be dark horse BHEL, where capex is reviving. If electric vehicles is the theme, the BHEL network has the best transmission going across the country. From Rs 65-67, the stock has inched up to Rs 74. I do not rule out Rs 100, given the risk-on trade coming in 2020. Last year, when everyone was very bearish on PFC and REC, we stuck our neck out. Those stocks are up 50% and more given the dividend yields and are still looking strong. 

We suggest some of the PSU basket stocks, the CPSE ETF or alternatively Engineers India, NBCC, BEL, IGL and GAIL. GAIL cum bonus at these prices is giving you a very good opportunity. Either you buy that or buy the CPSE ETF, which can deliver stellar returns in the next two years. 


Why are markets not getting excited about what is happening around us?It is the lull before the storm. The budget can be a game changer. Already, we are talking of interest waivers and some sort of increments on the housing sector. You are talking of an MSME distressed fund which is the need of the hour. The transmission of money to the end user after the IL&FS fiasco. That is where there will be keen monitoring. 

Also, consumption is raring to go. Look at the ground level, look at the numbers on both auto and capex. The stocks have bottomed out before the sector and this is just the lull before the storm. However for macros to kick in and earnings to catch up may take a quarter or so.

After October, you would see a very strong rally globally as well and in the Indian context, the underperformance of midcaps is now almost through. In next 18 months, we will see the best part of the equity market which we have seen in a long time. There will be broader outperformance of the midcaps. If you have a three-month window where you can sit and accumulate stocks. We think the budget can be a game changer in the near term.


Where are you shopping in NBFCs? Not everything is good but not everything is bad either?Correct. Bajaj Finance, HDFC and LIC Housing are the three in our pecking order and we stay with that. We are very contrarian on L&T Finance. We think most of the bad news is in the price. They have a strong parentage and the management has guided that they have provisioned well enough for most of the downside. For them, capitalisation will not be such a big issue and they have weathered the storm well. 

At a price of Rs 115, it offers a very good risk opportunity of at least a 50% upside given that the government is looking at the MSME space and seeing the mistrust goes ahead. I would also like to point out IndusInd Bank. It has corrected quite a bit because of this IndusInd Bharat Financial merger. But given that the commercial vehicle market is now looking to pick up in the next three months and the promoter is putting his money where his mouth is, they have just issued warrants at Rs 1,700. I cannot but be bullish and use this opportunity to buy IndusInd Bank as a contrarian. 

IndusInd deserves to be rerated over here and on more quarter of weakness where IL&FS provisioning is through you should start to see a very strong uptick on the credit and the NIMs. 


Would you say there is merit in buying cement stocks afresh even after the run-up that we have seen from the lows?If you have a slightly longer-term view, you cannot go wrong on cement. The monsoon and beyond that the return of pricing power will help. Already prices are fairly firm in most of the regions and going forward the whole impetus on a Rs 1 lakh-crore budget of spending, rural housing, rural income and the “housing for all” provide a huge impetus. 

Also, infrastructure growth is visible. For us, it would be UltraTech, ACC and Shree Cement in that pecking order. A dark horse on a midcap would be JK Lakshmi Cement and will standout over a period of time given that its cost of production is the lowest in the midcap stocks.

The grass is always greener on the other side.

Some analysts prefer to say the same thing about the e-commerce businesses, the biggest buzz in the industry lately. 

Some unlisted e-commerce names such as ANI Technologies (Ola), Oravel Stays (Oyo Rooms) and One97 Communications (Paytm) have been creating quite a splash in the unlisted market, mainly on the strength of their titular value, drawing in small and retail investors.

Many such investors flocking to these counters are not even aware of the challenges of the unlisted space, especially with regard value fluctuation and limited liquidity.

Many are drawn to such propositions on the lure of attractive valuations and herd mentality.


Stock prices & financial performance
According to Abhishek Securities, a firm dealing in unlisted shares, Ola, Oyo Rooms and Paytm are currently priced at Rs 27,500, Rs 75,000 and Rs 17,000, respectively, in the unlisted space.

That, even when these companies continue to incur losses. One 97 Communications, which houses the main payments business of Paytm, reported an over four-fold rise in consolidated revenue in FY18 at Rs 3,314.8 crore but losses swelled to Rs 1,606.05 crore from Rs 903.09 crore in FY17, as per data sourced from Tofler.

Meanwhile, Paytm Mall reported a loss of Rs 1,787.55 crore on a total revenue of Rs 774.86 crore in FY18, as it looks to compete with Walmart-backed Flipkart and Amazon India, which together hold 80 per cent market share.

Combined losses of One 97 and Paytm Mall swelled 270 per cent to Rs 3,393 crore in FY18 from Rs 917 crore in FY17 while combined revenues went up by 417 per cent during the same period to Rs 4,089 crore.

For the year ended March 2018, OYO India reported a marginal widening of net loss to Rs 360 crore for India operations against Rs 355 crore loss reported for the previous financial year.

OYO India’s revenue growth has jumped over three-fold. The firm reported an operating revenue of Rs 416 crore for financial year 2018 compared with Rs 120 crore reported for financial year 2016-17. 

Flipkart India led the way with an unmatched margin. Net loss of the e-commerce giant grew over 700 per cent in FY18, though revenue growth during the period was 39 per cent. In FY18, Flipkart India reported a Rs Rs 2,060 crore loss against Rs 245 crore in the previous year.

What then justifies the sky-high valuations that these stocks are commanding in the unlisted space?

“Business models in e-commerce industry, in general, differ from traditional businesses. They do not owe or possess any tangible assets like land, plant, or warehouse. Also, they incur huge losses and do not have any other reserve as well. Despite this, their valuations keep going up to billions. Remember, Flipkart sold its controlling stake to Walmart at Rs 1.11 lakh crore,” says Sandip Ginodia of Abhishek Securities.

Dinesh Gupta, Partner at unlistedzone.com, explains the arithmetic of valuing an e-commerce entity. “E-commerce outfits are virtual shops and they are valued by their sales, at 10 to 15 times of annual sales. The multiple may be even higher in certain cases depending on growth stage of the segment,” he said.


What is the theory?
Fair value of any stock is very subjective till it gets listed. “Different sets of people can value the same thing using different methods to arrive at different numbers. Here, one sees value in something and the other does not,” says Ginodia.

Arun Mukherjee, a Kolkata-based value investor and co-founder of Sebi-registered SA Investment Advisors, says there is a ‘great fool theory’ at work behind the humungous valuations that these companies command.

“That theory says it is possible to make money by buying securities, whether or not they are overvalued, and by selling them for a profit at a later date. This is because there will always be someone (a bigger or greater fool) willing to pay a higher price,” he said.

Even the largest e-commerce company of the world, Amazon, does not make any money, Ginodia points out. e-commerce is a global trend, which is why such a company will be valued higher even when they do not have any asset or profits. Since there is no structural mechanism, they are inflating valuations at will.


A trend or a business?E-commerce is the new trend currently. But once sentiment weakens, investors may rush to offload them. 

“These companies are valued only on the basis of top line and the growth they show. It is very hard to arrive at fair value,” said Ginodia.

Gupta says when a company is not listed, it does not need to focus on investors. “It does not opt for any mechanism like rights issue or bonus issue, which may downgrade their stock value. This is why any valuation is considered okay.”

Again, price alone cannot be a determinant of attractiveness of a stock. MRF currently trades around Rs 55,000, at 20 times the EPS of Rs 2,600. 

“This is does mean that the stock is not investor-friendly. Similarly, if Wipro had not given any bonus or split its share, the stock value would have been Rs 5 lakh today. They split it to ensure liquidity for investors,” Gupta said.


Key concernsE-commerce stocks do not see much volume in the unlisted space, mostly because of high valuations. “If they are to be listed in the stock market, the valuation will not be even 1/100th of what they are demanding. They are priced so high, but you would still buy it thinking that some another buyer will come later on,” says Mukherjee. 

He said investors should be very cautious while investing in the unlisted space. 

“Flipkart is making billions of losses every year. You are making sales in penny, but are valued in millions. This is crazy. There is no logic in it. At some point, these bubbles will burst for sure,” Mukherjee said.

According to him, Indian customers fall for discounts and offers and this is what the e-commerce companies are tapping to do business. But this is unlikely to continue forever. They will not make any profit anytime soon, perhaps next three to five years. 


The contrarian viewSome analysts say some promoters, like those of the e-commerce giants, want their stocks to trade at a premium among select investors. This is why companies like MRF, Page Industries or Shree Cements do not opt for a stock split or bonus issues.

Ola has slashed all discounts and will be in profit in a year or two. People will be using Ola as they have got used to it now. At a later stage, Paytm may start charging a fee for its services. It is active in many services, which will, in turn, enhance revenue. This is be the business model and most e-commerce companies follow the same, said Gupta.

KOLKATA: Business leaders, Birla employees from schools and group companies, friends, well-wishers and relatives gathered to pay their last homage to Basant Kumar Birla at his residence 'Birla Park' on Gurusaday Road in Kolkata, on Thursday.

Harshavardhan Neotia of Ambuja Neotia Group, Hari Mohan and Prashant Bangur of Shree Cement, H P and Sanjay Budhia of Patton Group, N G Khaitan of Khaitan & Co, were among those who were present at 'Birla Park' where Basant Kumar Birla lay in state on a specially erected platform that was spread with red and white petals. Sides of the platform were lined with white flowers wreaths from friends, business houses, institutions and other dignitaries.

There was a sizable presence from academia and the consular corps who had gathered to catch a last glimpse of their beloved leader and pay a floral tribute. However, it was the common person who took centre-stage. They came singly with modest offerings of a fistful of petals as well as in groups representing associations close to Basant Kumar Birla, carrying a flower wreaths which were placed with some difficulty beside the body. The crowd waited patiently in a queue that snaked through one of the busiest thoroughfares of the city, stretching up to a kilometre. Some brought wreaths — big and small. Some came with a single rose bud, holding it close to the chest, lest it wilts.

Grandson Kumar Mangalam Birla, his family members and close relatives stood beside the body during the most part before proceeding towards Kalighat crematorium for the final lap of the Birla Group patriarch's journey slightly past 1 pm on the auspicious day of the Rath Yatra. Members of the Birla family including the patriarch's daughters Manjushree Khaitan and Jayshree Mohta, prominent Birla family members such as S K Birla and son Sidharth, and CK Birla bade an emotional adieu to the patriarch. 

The tall, silver-haired aristocratic industrialist B K Birla breathed his last at his Mumbai residence Wednesday afternoon. His cremation happened in Kolkata on Thursday in accordance with his 'express wishes'.

With his ancestors serving as powerful role models, teenage entrepreneur Basant Kumar pursued business activity with a passion that no one could quite curb, including his father Ghanshyam Das Birla who he greatly revered and regarded. However, he was drawn into a lot of simultaneous personal and co-curricular activity to fan an all round personality development that prevented him from becoming a 'business-worm'. Over the years, and with wife Sarala, he built up a formidable collection of sculptures, paintings and other art objects — many of which have been turned over to the Birla Academy of Art & Culture in Kolkata.

"Basant Kumar Birla was a distinguished industrialist who contributed to our nation’s prosperity. He also made a mark as an exceptional philanthropist. His passion for education was well-known. My thoughts are with his family and well-wishers in this hour of grief. Om Shanti," Prime Minister Narendra Modi tweeted.

Birla’s death has created a void that could not be filled, the Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee said, recalling the 2013 Banga Bibhushan honour the state government conferred on him. President Ram Nath Kovind said: “Sorry to hear about the passing away of veteran industrialist Shri B K Birla. He made crucial contributions to business, education and several social causes.”

Net profits of Nifty 50 companies could climb 29 per cent on-year in the June quarter on expectations that some of the banks, which had shown significant asset stress a year ago, would perform better. Revenue will likely expand 7.4 per cent and log single-digit growth for the first time in nine quarters, reflecting higher base effect and slowing demand.

Banks, construction and cement companies, and capital-goods makers are likely to do better, given the higher rate of loan recoveries, increased capacity utilisation at plants, and rising prices. Automobile, consumer goods, metal and telecom companies are expected to report subdued earnings.

“The first-quarter corporate results will have the large base of Q1FY19 as an impediment. High-frequency data in India for Q1FY20 have been largely weak, although some respite was seen in steel and power generation in the first two months of the fiscal,” said Deepak Jasani, research head, HDFC Securities.

“The consumer space has also been facing a slowdown, compounded by tightness in the credit markets,” said Jasani of HDFC Securities.

Operating margin is expected to contract by 100 basis points (one percentage point) to 20.9 per cent in the June quarter. But it will still be better than the 18 per cent operating margin of the March 2019 quarter.

Growth momentum for the rest of FY20 hinges on the pace of demand recovery in various pockets of the economy — rural and urban consumption, and industry.

“The economy continues to suffer from slowdown across sectors and tight liquidity. All eyes are now on the budget and the extent to which these concerns will be addressed,” said Jasani.



SECTOR EXPECTATIONS

AUTOMOBILES
Earnings at auto companies will be under pressure for the second consecutive quarter owing to a sharp contraction in volume growth and lower capacity utilisation. Volume growth of passenger cars, two-wheelers and commercial vehicles dropped 10-22 per cent during the quarter following rising channel inventory. India’s largest car maker Maruti Suzuki’s volumes fell 19 per cent in the quarter, while Hero MotoCorp’s volumes dropped 12 per cent.


BANKING
The declining rate of fresh nonperforming loans at several banks is a major positive for the sector that has been battling poor asset quality for the past several quarters. State Bank of India, Axis Bank and ICICI Bank should report profit recoveries. Retail-oriented lenders, such as HDFC Bank and IndusInd Bank, may report a further slowdown in credit offtake, in lockstep with slowing consumer demand.


CAPITAL GOODS
Capital expenditure by state governments and the public sector is likely to support the performance of capital goods companies. In addition, order inflows during general elections have been better than Street estimates.


CEMENT
The effect of rising cement prices was not fully visible in the previous quarter. In the June quarter, large cement companies are expected to benefit from the spillover effect of higher prices. Also, cement production in May rose 2-3 per cent on-year. Revenues of UltraTech, ACC, Ambuja Cements, Shree Cement and Dalmia Bharat are expected to rise by 10-15 per cent and net profit by 5-7 per cent.


FMCGThe June quarter results are likely to be affected by a slowdown in demand due to weak macroeconomic conditions amid water scarcity in rural India. FMCG companies are likely to post single-digit volume growth. Advertising spend may remain high as companies continue to invest in brands. The key factor to watch would be management commentaries on consumer demand in an environment of erratic rainfall and a broader economic slowdown.


IT
While the June quarter has traditionally been a good quarter for Indian IT companies, unfavourable currency movements and slower project ramp-ups in some cases may affect top line growth. TCS and Infosys are expected to report 2-2.5 per cent sequential growth in dollar-denominated revenues. Operating margins are likely to be under pressure.


METALS
Lower metal prices and slowdown in the local auto industry will likely affect earnings at metal companies, although a relatively weaker rupee may partially help offset the impact. Prices of steel, aluminium and zinc have fallen by up to 25 per cent from their peaks of last year, which should hit profitability.


PHARMA
Pharma companies are likely to continue their improved performance seen in the preceding quarter. While there are no major positives, price erosion in the US market has peaked, aiding their performance in the key market. Cost rationalisation on the R&D front is likely to continue. Sun Pharma, Aurobindo Pharma and Cipla are expected to register improved performances.


TELECOM
A gradual decline in pressure on billing rates is the big takeaway for listed telecom companies. This may lead to a modest increase in revenue, but profitability may not improve much due to the intense competition.

By Rajesh N Naidu

In the past three years, in terms of returns, ET Cement Index (covers key cement companies) and ET Construction Index (covers prominent construction companies) have been unable to beat the benchmark index Nifty by a wide margin. A key cause for this has been valuation of these companies. But now, with the broad market fall, the valuation of select cement and construction companies seemed to be in the fair range.

To boost further sentiment in these counters is the proposed investments in the infrastructure segment by the government in the Union Budget. Let us understand investments in the housing sector. As regards, urban areas, the government has sanctioned close to Rs 4.83 lakh crore in order to construct 81 lakh houses. According to the Union Budget document, construction of 47 lakh houses have already begun. As regards rural areas, through Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana – Gramin (PMAY-G), between FY20 and FY22, the government proposes to construct 1.95 crore houses. In the past five years, the government has constructed close to 1.54 crore rural homes.

In the third phase of Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana, the government plans to construct 1,25,000 km of roads in the next five years. This would entail an estimated investment of Rs 80250 crore. In all, the government plans to invest Rs 100 lakh crore in infrastructure sector in the next five years.

Among the construction companies, select well-placed companies which have superior execution capabilities and relatively higher number of financial closure to their projects are likely to see increased interest from the street. These companies are KNR Constructions, PNC Infratech, Dilip Buildcon and Ashoka Buildcon. Among cement companies, those companies which have enhanced capacity through acquisition or organic route, stand to benefit considerably. These companies are Ultratech Cement, Dalmia Bharat, Shree Cement, and The Ramco Cements. 

In the past three years, ET Cement index has given 22 per cent returns while Nifty has given 45.6 per cent in the same period. In the past three years, ET Construction index has given 48.9 per cent while the Nifty has given 45.6 per cent in the same period. In the next three years, the aforementioned counters are likely to generate high interest given the increase source of orders from the government's humongous investments in infrastructure sector.

By Nupur Acharya

A slowdown in economic growth amid the trade dispute between the world’s biggest economies has put Indian corporate earnings at risk, analysts say.

“It’s the confluence of headwinds -- weak global demand, fading impact of rupee depreciation, non-bank finance company crisis and scale-back of government spending -- which is deepening the slowdown,” Edelweiss Securities Ltd. analysts led by Prateek Parekh said in a note.

The country’s economic growth slumped to a five-year low of 5.8 per cent in January-March. The absence of any substantial fiscal stimulus for companies in the federal budget last week puts the onus back on the government to spur growth. The Reserve Bank of India has already cut interest rates three times this year and signaled more easing to come.

Edelweiss expects profits for companies in the NSE Nifty 50 Index rose 7 per cent year-on-year in the April-June period. The broker sees profit expansion concentrated in just a few sectors, namely financials, airlines, pharmaceuticals and cement.

Here’s what analysts expect from the results season that kicks off Tuesday with Asia’s top software exporter, Tata Consultancy Services Ltd.


Reliance Securities (Naveen Kulkarni)



Expect “uninspiring” 1Q earnings. Nifty company profits are likely to grow by just 6 per cent, led by banks and financial services stocks.
Autos will be the major drag on earnings.
Inventory losses at oil marketing companies will hurt profits for the oil and gas sector.
Consumer sector will see growth challenges. Price growth is critical as volume growth tapers. Titan Co. Ltd., ITC Ltd., Hindustan Unilever Ltd. and Marico Ltd. top picks.
Building materials, infrastructure and capital goods will see healthy earnings. Top results picks are Ultratech, JK Cement, KEC International and Larsen & Toubro.


Dolat Capital



Agrochemicals and specialty chemicals are potential winners.
Auto companies are expected to report sharp drops in profits. Bajaj Auto Ltd. and TVS Motor Co Ltd are likely to report relatively better performance.
Kotak Mahindra Bank Ltd and HDFC Bank Ltd are likely to perform above par, but improvement in net interest margins is expected to remain marginal as funding costs are unlikely to taper materially.
Expect revenue growth to remain muted for consumer companies due to the liquidity crunch in the first half of the quarter.
Expect revenue momentum to continue for software exporters due to strong deal signings in 4Q. Cross-currency movement will have a negative impact of 10-50 bps on the dollar revenue of Indian IT vendors.


Edelweiss Securities (Prateek Parekh)



Auto margins are expected to be range-bound due to poor volumes. The benefits of relatively lower commodity costs are expected to be offset by company efforts to reduce inventories. Ashok Leyland, Mahindra & Mahindra Ltd. and Eicher Motors are top picks.
Tight liquidity, risk aversion and slower growth dent the earnings outlook for shadow lenders. Their overall assets under management likely grew 2.1 per cent q/q and 12.8 per cent y/y.
Among banks, those with robust deposits, pricing flexibility and ability to aggressively raise deposits have an edge. Edelweiss prefers ICICI Bank, SBI and Kotak Mahindra Bank; among NBFCs, the picks are Housing Development Finance Corp Ltd and Mahindra & Mahindra Frinancial Services Ltd.
Sharp price hikes and easing fuel costs will offset impact of low demand for cement companies. Top picks are Shree Cement and JK Cement Ltd.
Consumer goods companies will post weak volume growth overall. Sees Britannia and Marico posting strongest growth, at over 6 per cent.
Positive on software exporters on basis of demand; prefer large caps due to execution capabilities, investment ability and better valuations. Buy on Infosys Ltd, Tech Mahindra Ltd. and HCL Technologies Ltd., Hold on Tata Consultancy Services Ltd. and Wipro Ltd.


Kotak Institutional Equities (Sanjeev Prasad)


The outlook is positive for corporate banks ICICI Bank and SBI given their inexpensive valuations and visibility of steady progress toward RoE “normalization.” Yes Bank will face one of its most challenging quarters. There is more focus on asset quality for IndusInd Bank Ltd. and RBL Bank Ltd.
Expect sharp improvement in profits for Indigo on higher yields and after Jet Airways stopped functioning.
Reliance Industries is likely to report a marginal q/q increase in standalone Ebitda led by higher refining margins, an increase in crude throughput and petchem volumes.

As many as 16 Indian companies, including IT bigwigs Infosys and TCS, have expressed worries about the risks of climate change to their businesses in the next five years, according to a report. The 16 Indian companies are in various sectors like banking, cement, IT, consumer goods, automobiles, electric utility, mining, gas processing and distribution, business and financial services and textiles, the report by global forum Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP) stated.

"As climate change threats are on the rise, risks to businesses are also correspondingly increasing. A group of world's biggest companies representing nearly 17 trillion US Dollars (USD) in market capitalization have valued the climate risks to their businesses at almost 1 trillion USD - with many likely to hit within the next five years," the report said. The CDP is a global disclosure system that enables companies, cities, states and regions to measure and manage their environmental impacts. It collects and collates self-reported environmental data in the world.

The data was collected by the CDP and compiled into a report after over 200 global companies, including 16 Indian businesses responded to its questionnaire and shared threats to their business due to water scarcity. The Indian companies are - Infosys Ltd, Tata Consultancy Services(TCS), GAIL, Axis Bank, Kotak Mahindra Bank, State Bank of India, Mahindra and Mahindra Financial Services, Hindustan Zinc, Indian Hotels Co. Ltd, Shree Cement, Tata Chemicals, Tata Global Beverages, Tata Motors, Tata Power Co, Wipro and Arvind Ltd, a textile company.

Infosys and TCS expressed concern over their workforce and operations being affected due to climate change and the changes in the availability of natural resources like water in regions where they operate. "A significant proportion of our workforce is based out of offices in coastal cities like Mumbai, Chennai and Kolkata which have high exposure to extreme weather events like precipitation, cyclones, rise in sea level, etc," the report said quoting TCS.

According to the report, banks and financial institutions lend money to a myriad of industries that face direct climate risks such as increased instances of natural disasters, depletion of water resources and impact on human capital. It said that Axis Bank is a lender to the agricultural sector, which has a high risk of crop failures or disruptions in production due to floods, droughts, cyclones and other natural disasters.

"The disasters affect the production capacity and ability of industries lying in their wake. The Bank is a significant lender to all such sectors, and thus these risks also impact its own portfolio," it said. SBI, which also has a significant agricultural portfolio, told the CDP that the negative effect of climate change and increased probability of droughts will adversely affect loans to be paid back in time, thereby leaving it susceptible to credit risk.

Gas processing and distribution company GAIL is also at the risk of being hit by climate change as its major compressor station and pipeline installation is located near the sea and is highly vulnerable to get adversely impacted due to rising sea levels. "Rising sea levels would for certain impact our coastal facilities and can lead to even closure of operations in the worst case. Even higher probability occurrence is likely floods due to storm surges becoming more frequent," the report said quoting GAIL.

Hindustan Zinc, the mining company said it has three smelters and five mines located in Rajasthan, so change in the precipitation level is one of the major risk areas for it. "Change in precipitation level further intensifies the problem as our operations in mining and smelter industry are heavily dependent on water availability. If there is less rainfall in these areas in future, it may affect our operations and productivity due to inadequate supply of water leading to a direct impact on company's revenue."

Reliance Securities has given a hold recommendation on Ramco Cements (TRCL) with a target price of Rs 770.

Shares of Ramco Cements traded at Rs 772 around 2:45 pm on 18 July, 2019. The brokerage has set a one-year horizon for the stock to hit the target price.

"We maintain our hold recommendation on the stock with a revised target price of Rs 770 (valuing at 12 times of FY21 Ebitda)," said the brokerage.


View of the brokerage: 


Cement-clinker (cc) ratio dips marginallyTRCL’s Cement-Clinker (CC) ratio for FY19 marginally declined to 1.30 times against 1.32 times in FY18 mainly due to significant reduction in blending and higher OPC demand in its key Southern markets. 

Fly-ash and slag blending in percentage per tonne of cement reduced to 24.6 per cent and 59.1 per cent, respectively in FY19. 

While there have hardly been any clinker sales, it has doubled its export during the year to Rs 110 crore. 

However, likely pick-up in Eastern sales volume post new GUs will aid to improve the ratio. Its annual clinker production grew by 20 per cent YoY to 8.62mnT.


Interest bearing debt increased significantly by Rs 600 crore
While consolidated gross debt increased by Rs 520 crore to Rs 1,640 crore (standalone debt at Rs 1,620 crore), interest-bearing loan increased by Rs 620 crore to Rs 1,490 crore in FY19, as interest free deferred sale tax loan declined from Rs 250 crore against Rs 150 crore in FY18. 

"Going forward, we expect its gross debt to increase from Rs 1,640 crore to Rs 2,000 crore in FY21E despite TRCL is likely to incur more than Rs 2,370 crore in next two years for its ongoing capex programme," said the brokerage.


FCF turns negative after six years on cost pressure, soft realisation & higher capex
An increase of Rs 145 per tonne in operating cost per tonne and over about 5 per cent year-on-year (YoY) decline in blended realisation led to decline in interest adjusted OCF to Rs 740 crore in FY19 against Rs 1,050 crore in FY18 despite a sharp about 19.4 per cent YoY increase in sales volume. 

Notably, higher fuel and input prices led to increase in opex. Further, TRCL reported a negative FCF of Rs 410 crore after six years led by higher capex of about Rs 1,200 crore. 

The brokerage believes stronger operating cash flow mainly due to higher realisation and benign cost environment are likely to turn its FCF positive in the current fiscal itself.


Board composition still remains static; two key executives account for 10 per cent of profit
As per the brokerage, TRCL’s board members continued to remain static despite inclusion of M.F. Farooqi in FY18 in place of P.R. Ramasubrahmaneya Rajha. 

The members of Audit Committee and Remuneration Committee also broadly remained static. 

However, Justice Chitra Venkataraman is inducted in Audit Committee during the year, while R.S. Agarwal continued to be the Chairman in Audit and Remuneration committees for several years. 

"We further note that TRCL’s top two executives drew about 10 per cent of annual profit, which is significantly higher in absolute terms than its peers and other conglomerate barring few," the brokerage said.


Depleting limestone reserves; a key concern 
TRCL highlights that since several state governments do not have required geological data for availability of limestone reserves, obtaining fresh mining leases by the companies will be delayed further. 

Notably, the existing limestone mines reserves of cement companies are depleting at faster rate and consequently shortened life span of the mines. 

As many as 106 mineral blocks were notified by state governments for conduct of auction, post amendment of MMDR 2015. However, only 54 blocks had been auctioned, out of which 24 blocks are limestone mines. 

TRCL states that out of the total auctioned blocks, only 4-5 blocks have reportedly come to the stage of production so far. Pan-India players like UltraTech, Ambuja and Shree Cement secured 2-3 mines each albeit at higher cost. 

"We reckon that average cost of securing limestone reserve fell to Rs 530 per tonne, which including 3 mines stood at Rs 1,000-1,300 per tonne," said the brokerage.


Strategic investments for two entities 
TRCL made strategic investments in two companies during the year with aggregating equity investment of Rs 16.2 crore. 

It invested Rs 4.5 crore and Rs 11.7 crore in Ramco Industrial & Technology Services (RITSL) and Lynks Logistics (LLL) , respectively. It indicated that these investments were made for the expansion of businesses. 

While RITS is a subsidiary of TRCL with 94 per cent financial interest, LLL is an associate company with 49 per cent financial interest. 

LLL is involved in goods transport services and generated revenue and net loss of Rs 40.6 crore and Rs 21.8 crore, respectively, in FY19. 

Similarly, RITSL is involved in businesses of supplying manpower and transportation of goods by road and IT services. Its revenue and net loss stood at Rs 35.9 crore and Rs 98 lakh, respectively, in FY19.


Outlook & valuation
Capacity expansion of 6.2mnT (40 per cent of existing capacity) for Rs 5,500 ($80 per tonne) without stretching its B/S with DE ratio of 0.3 time bodes well for TRCL. 

"We maintain our long-term positive view on TRCL on the back of sustained volume growth and improving operational efficiency. 

However, we marginally reduce our Ebitda estimate by 1 per cent/2.5 per cent for FY20E/FY21E mainly to factor in soft sales volume in Q1FY20," said the brokerage. 

At the current market price, the stock trades at 15.3 times and 13.1 times Ebitda of FY20E and FY21E, respectively, which appear to be fairly valued.

The next two quarters you should have a hunting list and just buy good businesses whenever there is a fall in the stock., says Devang Mehta, Head, Equity Advisory, Centrum Wealth Management. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.


The earnings season was kicked off by IT with a bang, particularly on TCS, but midway through, we see That some of the mid-tier banks for are seeing a little bit of pressure. Will pain persist for another couple of quarters? What is your takeaway from the earnings?The pain would probably last for a couple of quarters more. Why I say that is because the earnings were not as bad as people were expecting. It was more or less predicted to be a washout quarter but the numbers did not disappoint the Street though the commentaries are surely disappointing the street. 

Largecap as well as the mid-tier banks have all been talking about a demand slowdown -- right from HDFC Bank to even RBL Bank. The SME sector is slowing down, the problem of credit which has struck the economy since the last seven, eight months, all have been deterrents for the economy and market. Plus, in consumer names, Dabur numbers were excellent, A 9.7% volume growth is an aberration in this type of an environment.

But if you listen to the commentary of this management. there was not much optimism for the next couple of quarters. So yes, there can probably be pain. If you ask me whether it is a blue sky scenario, no. But is it an opportunity in adversity? The answer is yes. The next two quarters you should have a hunting list and just buy good businesses whenever there is a fall in the stock. 


We are expecting some amount of a decline in volumes this time. Even though cement has been looked at favourably lately, in terms of earnings we are expecting to see revenues as well as PAT a little lower for Ambuja. What are your expectations and what is your view on the cement names right now?Clearly we have been quite positive on cement names. A few like UltraTech or Shree Cement has been bought into the portfolios in the last six, nine months. And yes, what a run it has had during this trying times. 

Clearly the budget which laid down a little bit of impetus on infrastructure plus housing for all -- is one segment. Low-cost housing or housing for all which still keeps on growing in an overall pessimistic segment. 

Our sense is that cement demand, cement realisations as well as capacity utilisations in the last couple of quarters has been trending upwards. So, cement probably merits a place in the portfolio. It looks more a cyclical story but for the next three years, it looks to be a structural story. We would probably consider cement with the more frontline names rather than the midcap names.


What about Yes Bank? On the back of the fund raising exercise that they are currently undergoing, there are still some concerns that given the state of the bank, the valuations will completely go out of the window and it might actually be difficult. On the other hand you got news coming in that some of these PE funds are just lining up to be part of that QIP. Would you still buy into a Yes Bank in case they are able to raise those funds or would you be completely averse to the story?We have been avoiding accidents at this point of time because as I said, quality has commended some premium in the market. I would not be able to comment on individual stocks but the sense here is that when your largecaps or market leaders also start to fall, buy the market leaders. If these stocks are too expensive, buy the next big one. If you feel that Asian Paints is costly, and that there are companies like Berger Paints, go in for Asian Paints and Berger Paints. We tend to remain with a couple of more market leaders rather than going into the space where we feel there will be difficulties in terms of not only losing market share but also losing business while you get into your balance sheet issues and sort those out.


Just when the sector dynamics were beginning to look up for telecom and most of these companies were beginning to deleverage, and the Street was also turning pretty bullish in the prospects of Bharti Airtel. Now comes this dampener in the form of big fines on Airtel and Idea Vodafone.We remain very cautious on this sector. In fact, we have not bought this sector in the last two-three years. My sense is though the debt equation was getting lower and the market was divided into three companies which are ruling the roost, it is still a crowded trade. Lots of people buy it as a contra trade but we would still avoid it. As you said, there are lots of such issues which can creep up and whenever the auction comes up, debt issues will come to the fore. Avoid this sector. There is so much of fall happening in the broader markets. The best stocks have started falling in the last 8-10 days. There are better opportunities to be in this type of businesses rather than being in the telecom sector at this point. 


Canara Bank and quite a few other banks have come out with numbers. Today it is the turn of Bank of Baroda. We can’t compare the numbers to last year’s because of the overall merger, but what is it that you are expecting?The earnings growth of a lot of these banks would be fair and watched into. In the last couple of quarters, there have been a lot of recoveries. The NPA has come down for a lot of PSU and corporate banks as well and the mettle of taking the earnings growth of Nifty or Sensex of the benchmark indices has been more or less done by all these banks. 

I think there would be a recovery at least in terms of sentiment for a lot of these banks. Probably PSU banks would not be in the hunting list but there seems to be enough evidence that with interest rates heading downwards, with inflation also trending down and probably a little bit of a boost or sentiment booster from the government or from the RBI would go a long way in giving the banks that extra zig. 
I can say that the BFSI sector which has been the darling of the market before the big fall, could continue and banks again probably could lead the rise whenever it starts.

By Chandan Taparia 

Nifty opened negative on Wednesday and drifted towards the 11,000 mark, but bounced back from lower levels in the latter part of the session. It formed a Bullish Candle on the daily scale, but continued to form lower highs and lows, which has been seen for last three sessions. 

The index remained highly volatile throughout the day. The overall structure of the index is under pressure. As long as it holds below 11,250, it could extend its weakness towards the psychological support at 11,000 and then 10,950 levels, while on the upside hurdles are seen at 11,200 and then 11,250 levels.

On the options front, maximum Put open interest was at 11,000 followed by 11,200 while maximum Call OI was at 11,500 followed by 11,300. There was Put writing at 11,000 followed by 11,100 levels while Call writing was seen at 11,100 followed by 11,500. Options data suggested a trading range between 10,800 and 11,300 levels.

India VIX fell 0.15 per cent to 13.59 level.

Bank Nifty drifted towards the 29,550 mark but bounced back sharply towards 29,000. It formed a Bullish Candle on the daily scale as it closed above its opening levels. It has been forming lower lows from last two sessions. However, it has broken the rising trend line, which was formed by connecting the swing lows of 25,599, 26,617, 26,719 and 28,871 levels. As long as the index holds below 29,000 level, weakness could be seen towards 28,550 and then 28,388 levels, while on the upside hurdles are seen at 29,250 and then 29,500 levels.

Nifty futures closed positive at 11,128 with a gain of 0.30 per cent. Long buildup was seen in RBL Bank, Chola Finance, BEL and TVS Motor while shorts were seen in Bharti Airtel, Siemens and Shree Cements.


(Chandan Taparia is Technical & Derivative Analyst at MOFSL. Investors are advised to consult financial advisers before taking an investment calls based on these observations)
